abstract: Pebble in the Sky is a science fiction novel by American writer [[Isaac Asimov|Isaac Asimov]], published in 1950. This work is his first novel — parts of the [[Foundation series|The Foundation Series]] had appeared from 1942 onwards, in magazines, but [[Foundation|Foundation (Isaac Asimov novel)]] was not published in book form until 1951. The original Foundation books are also a string of linked episodes, whereas this is a complete story involving a single group of characters.
title: Pebble in the Sky

abstract: The Critique of Pure Reason () is a 1781 book by the German philosopher [[Immanuel Kant|Immanuel Kant]], in which the author seeks to determine the limits and scope of [[metaphysics|metaphysics]]. A heavily-revised second edition was published in 1787. Also referred to as Kant's "First Critique", it was followed by the [[Critique of Practical Reason|Critique of Practical Reason]] (1788) and the [[Critique of Judgment|Critique of Judgment]] (1790). In the preface to the first edition, Kant explains that by a "critique of pure reason" he means not "a critique of books and systems, but of the faculty of reason in general, in respect of all knowledge after which it may strive independently of all experience" and that he aims to reach a decision about "the possibility or impossibility of metaphysics". The First Critique is often viewed as culminating several centuries of [[early-modern philosophy|early modern philosophy]], and inaugurating [[modern philosophy|western philosophy#Late modern (19th-century)]].
title: Critique of Pure Reason

abstract: The manual was first published in 1876 by U.S. Army officer [[Henry Martyn Robert|Henry Martyn Robert]], who adapted the rules and practice of [[Congress|United States Congress]] to the needs of non-legislative societies. Ten subsequent editions have been published, including major revisions in 1915 and 1970. The copyright to Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised is owned by the Robert's Rules Association, which selects by contract an authorship team to continue the task of revising and updating the book. The 11th and current edition was published in 2011.
title: Robert's Rules of Order

abstract: English As She Is Spoke is the common name of a 19th-century book written by Pedro Carolino, and falsely additionally credited to José da Fonseca, which was intended as a [[Portuguese|Portuguese language]]–[[English|English language]] conversational [[guide|guide]] or [[phrase book|phrase book]], but is regarded as a classic source of [[unintentional humour|unintentional humour]], as the given English translations are generally completely incoherent.
title: English As She Is Spoke

abstract: The Ancestor's Tale: A Pilgrimage to the Dawn of Life is a 2004 [[popular science|popular science]] book by [[Richard Dawkins|Richard Dawkins]], with contributions from Dawkins' research assistant Yan Wong. It follows the path of humans backwards through [[evolution|evolutionary]] history, meeting humanity's cousins as they converge on common ancestors. Dawkins' longest book to date, it was nominated for the [[2005 Aventis Prize for Science Books|The Aventis Prizes for Science Books#2005 Winner]].
title: The Ancestor's Tale

abstract: Star Wars: Heir to the Empire is a 1991 [[Star Wars|Star Wars]] novel by [[Timothy Zahn|Timothy Zahn]], and the first book in the [[Thrawn trilogy|Thrawn trilogy]]. It reached #1 on the [[New York Times Best Seller list|The New York Times Best Seller list]].
title: Heir to the Empire

abstract: Anatomy of Criticism: Four Essays ([[Princeton University Press|Princeton University Press]], 1957) is a book by Canadian literary critic and theorist, [[Northrop Frye|Herman Northrop Frye]], which attempts to formulate an overall view of the scope, theory, principles, and techniques of [[literary criticism|literary criticism]] derived exclusively from literature. Frye consciously omits all specific and practical criticism, instead offering classically inspired theories of modes, symbols, myths and genres, in what he termed "an interconnected group of suggestions." The literary approach proposed by Frye in Anatomy was highly influential in the decades before [[deconstructivist criticism|deconstruction]] and other expressions of [[postmodernism|postmodernism]] came to prominence in American academia circa 1980s.
title: Anatomy of Criticism

abstract: Le Chercheur d'or is a novel written in [[French|French language]] by [[French|France]] [[Nobel laureate|Nobel Prize in Literature]] writer [[J. M. G. Le Clézio|J. M. G. Le Clézio]] and translated into English as The prospector by Carol Marks and published by David R. Godine, Boston.
title: Le Chercheur d'or

abstract: Scouting for Boys (1908) was Baden-Powell's rewrite of his earlier book Aids to Scouting (1899) with many youth training ideas openly taken from The Birch Bark Roll of the Woodcraft Indians (1906) written by [[Ernest Thompson Seton|Ernest Thompson Seton]], who later became the Chief Scout of the Boy Scouts of America. Aids to Scouting was mostly a written explanation of the military scouting and self-reliance skills lessons Baden-Powell had learned from [[Frederick Russell Burnham|Frederick Russell Burnham]], the British Army Chief of Scouts, but following the [[siege of Mafeking|siege of Mafeking]] this military handbook unexpectedly became popular with many youth groups and educators, like [[Charlotte Mason|Charlotte Mason]], in Britain. At Mafeking, Baden-Powell's adjutant had recruited and trained boys aged 12–15 as cadets and during the siege they acted as postmen, messengers, and later to carry the wounded, to free men for fighting. Upon his return to England, following the [[Second Boer War|Second Boer War]], Baden-Powell learned some British schools had been using Aids to Scouting to teach [[observation|observation]] and [[deduction|Deductive reasoning]]. In 1906, Seton discussed youth training ideas with Baden-Powell and shared with him a copy of The Birch Bark Roll of the Woodcraft Indians. Soon after, Baden-Powell decided to revise Aids to Scouting into a book for boys. Several friends supported Baden-Powell, including Sir [[William Alexander Smith|William Alexander Smith (Boys' Brigade)]], founder of the [[Boys' Brigade|Boys' Brigade]], [[Cyril Arthur Pearson|Cyril Arthur Pearson]], who owned newspapers and printing presses, and the novelist [[Maria Fetherstonhaugh|Maria Fetherstonhaugh]], who provided a quiet Wimbledon house where he could write. Baden-Powell wrote a draft, then called Boy Patrols, which he used and tested with 22 boys for one week at [[camp on Brownsea Island|Brownsea Island Scout camp]] in the summer of 1907, where Pearson's literary editor [[Percy Everett|Percy Everett]] assisted.
title: Scouting for Boys

abstract: The Craft of Research is a book by [[Wayne C. Booth|Wayne C. Booth]], [[Gregory G. Colomb|Gregory G. Colomb]], [[Joseph M. Williams|Joseph M. Williams]], Joseph Bizup, and [[William T. Fitzgerald|William T. Fitzgerald]]. The work is published by the [[University of Chicago Press|University of Chicago Press]]. The book aims to provide a basic overview of how to research, from the process of selecting a topic and gathering sources to the process of writing results. The book has become a standard text in college composition classes and is now in its fourth edition.
title: The Craft of Research

abstract: Shadows Over Baker Street is an anthology of stories, each by a different author and each concerning an exploit of [[Arthur Conan Doyle|Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s [[Sherlock Holmes|Sherlock Holmes]] set against the backdrop of [[H. P. Lovecraft|H. P. Lovecraft]]'s [[Cthulhu Mythos|Cthulhu Mythos]]. The collection is edited by Michael Reaves and John Pelan, who also contributed the introduction. Doyle's estate approved the book.
title: Shadows Over Baker Street

abstract: Anno Dracula is a 1992 novel by British writer [[Kim Newman|Kim Newman]], the first in the [[Anno Dracula series|Anno Dracula series]]. It is an [[alternate history|alternate history]] using 19th-century English historical settings and personalities, along with characters from popular fiction. The interplay between humans who have chosen to "turn" into vampires and those who are "warm" (humans) is the backdrop for the plot which tracks [[Jack the Ripper|Jack the Ripper]]'s politically charged destruction of vampire prostitutes. The reader is alternately and sympathetically introduced to various points of view. The main characters are Jack the Ripper, and his hunters Charles Beauregard (an agent of [[the Diogenes Club|the Diogenes Club]]), and [[Geneviève Dieudonné|Geneviève Dieudonné]], an elder vampire. The two other main point of views are Captain Kostaki, a sympathetic elder vampire warrior of Dracula's Carpathian Guard, and Lord Godalming, ambitious, scheming aide of Prime Minister [[Ruthven|Lord Ruthven (vampire)]].
title: Anno Dracula

abstract: The Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure (formerly the Sturgis Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure by [[Alice Sturgis|Alice Sturgis]]) is a book of [[rules of order|rules of order]]. It is the second most popular [[parliamentary authority|parliamentary authority]] in the United States after [[Robert's Rules of Order|Robert's Rules of Order]]. It was first published in 1950. Following the death of the original author in 1975, the third (1988) and fourth (2001) editions of this work were revised by a committee of the [[American Institute of Parliamentarians|American Institute of Parliamentarians]]. In April 2012, a new book, entitled American Institute of Parliamentarians Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure (AIPSC) was released.
title: The Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure

abstract: The Institutes of the Lawes of England are a series of legal treatises written by Sir [[Edward Coke|Edward Coke]]. They were first published, in stages, between 1628 and 1644. Widely recognized as a foundational document of the [[common law|common law]], they have been cited in over 70 cases decided by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court of the United States]], including several [[landmark case|landmark cases]]. For example, in [[Roe v. Wade|Roe v. Wade]] (1973), Coke's Institutes are cited as evidence that under old English common law, an [[abortion|abortion]] performed before [[quickening|quickening]] was not an [[indictable offence|indictable offence]]. In the much earlier case of [[United States v. E. C. Knight Co.|United States v. E. C. Knight Co.]] (1895), Coke's Institutes are quoted at some length for their definition of [[monopolies|monopoly]]. The Institutes's various reprinted editions well into the 19th century is a clear indication of the long lasting value placed on this work throughout especially the 18th century in Britain and Europe. It has also been associated through the years with high literary connections. For example, [[David Hume|David Hume]] in 1764 requested it from the bookseller [[Andrew Millar|Andrew Millar]] in a cheap format for a French friend.
title: Institutes of the Lawes of England

abstract: The Flora Europaea is a 5-volume encyclopedia of plants, published between 1964 and 1993 by [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge University Press]]. The aim was to describe all the national [[Flora|Floras]] of Europe in a single, authoritative publication to help readers identify any wild or widely cultivated plant in Europe to the [[subspecies|subspecies]] level. It also provides information on geographical distribution, [[habitat|habitat]] preference, and [[chromosome|chromosome]] number, where known.
title: Flora Europaea

abstract: As a first-time novelist, Niffenegger had trouble finding a [[literary agent|literary agent]]. She eventually sent the novel to [[MacAdam/Cage|MacAdam/Cage]] unsolicited and, after an auction took place for the rights, Niffenegger selected them as her publishers. The book became a bestseller after an endorsement from author and family friend [[Scott Turow|Scott Turow]] on [[The Today Show|Today (NBC program)]], and as of March 2009 had sold nearly 2.5 million copies in the United States and the United Kingdom. Many reviewers were impressed with Niffenegger's unique perspectives on time travel. Some praised her characterization of the couple, applauding their emotional depth; others criticized her writing style as melodramatic and the plot as emotionally trite. The novel won the [[Exclusive Books Boeke Prize|Exclusive Books Boeke Prize]] and a [[British Book Award|British Book Award]]. [[A film version|The Time Traveler's Wife (film)]] was released in August 2009.
title: The Time Traveler's Wife

abstract: The Book of the Short Sun (1999–2001) is a series of three [[science fantasy|science fantasy]] novels or one [[three-volume novel|three-volume novel]] by the [[American|United States]] author [[Gene Wolfe|Gene Wolfe]]. It continues [[The Book of the Long Sun|The Book of the Long Sun]] (1993–1996): they share a narrator and Short Sun recounts a search for Silk, the Long Sun hero. The two works are set in the same universe as [[The Book of the New Sun|The Book of the New Sun]] series that Wolfe inaugurated in 1980 and the [[Internet Speculative Fiction Database|Internet Speculative Fiction Database]] (ISFDB) catalogs all three as sub-series of the "Solar Cycle", along with some other writings.
title: The Book of the Short Sun

abstract: Josephine Mutzenbacher or The Story of a Viennese Whore, as Told by Herself () is an [[erotic novel|erotic literature]] first published anonymously in [[Vienna|Vienna]], [[Austria|Austria]] in [[1906|1906 in literature]]. The novel is famous in the German-speaking world, having been in print in both German and English for over 100 years and sold over 3 million copies, becoming an erotic bestseller.
title: Josephine Mutzenbacher

abstract: The Armies of the Night is a [[nonfiction novel|nonfiction novel]] written by [[Norman Mailer|Norman Mailer]] and published by [[New American Library|New American Library]] in 1968. It won the [[Pulitzer Prize for General Non-fiction|Pulitzer Prize for General Non-fiction]] and the [[National Book Award|National Book Award]] in [[category Arts and Letters|List of winners of the National Book Award#Arts and Letters]].
title: The Armies of the Night

abstract: The Melancholy Death of Oyster Boy & Other Stories is a [[1997|1997 in literature]] poetry book written and illustrated by film director [[Tim Burton|Tim Burton]]. The poems, which are full of [[black humor|black humor]], tell stories of hybrid kids, spontaneous transformers, and women who have babies to win over men.
title: The Melancholy Death of Oyster Boy & Other Stories

abstract: The Wisdom of Crowds: Why the Many Are Smarter Than the Few and How Collective Wisdom Shapes Business, Economies, Societies and Nations, published in 2004, is a book written by [[James Surowiecki|James Surowiecki]] about the aggregation of information in groups, resulting in decisions that, he argues, are often better than could have been made by any single member of the group. The book presents numerous case studies and [[anecdote|anecdotes]] to illustrate its argument, and touches on several fields, primarily [[economics|economics]] and [[psychology|psychology]].
title: The Wisdom of Crowds

abstract: The Encyclopedia of World Problems and Human Potential is published by the [[Union of International Associations|Union of International Associations]] (UIA). It is available online since 2000, and was previously available as a CD-ROM and as a three-volume book. The online Encyclopedia is currently in a redevelopment phase.
title: Encyclopedia of World Problems and Human Potential

abstract: The Krytos Trap (1996) is the third novel in the [[Star Wars: X-wing|Star Wars: X-wing (book series)]] series. It was written by [[Michael A. Stackpole|Michael A. Stackpole]]. It is set at the beginning of the New Republic Era in the Star Wars universe and focuses on the problems the [[New Republic|New Republic (Star Wars)]] has in occupying [[Coruscant|Coruscant]].
title: The Krytos Trap

abstract: The Midwich Cuckoos is a 1957 [[science fiction|science fiction]] novel written by the English author [[John Wyndham|John Wyndham]]. It tells the tale of an English village in which the women become pregnant by [[brood parasitic|brood parasite]] aliens.
title: The Midwich Cuckoos

abstract: When Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy came out in 1974, revelations exposing the presence of Soviet double agents in Britain were still fresh in public memory. [[Guy Burgess|Guy Burgess]], [[Donald Maclean|Donald Duart Maclean]], [[Anthony Blunt|Anthony Blunt]], [[John Cairncross|John Cairncross]], and [[Kim Philby|Kim Philby]], later known as the [[Cambridge Five|Cambridge Five]], had been exposed as [[KGB|KGB]] moles. The five had risen to very senior positions in branches of the British government. The book, based on the premise of uncovering a Soviet double agent in the SIS, offers a novelisation of this period. It is also set against the larger theme of the decline of British influence on the world stage after World War II, with the USA and the USSR emerging as the dominant superpowers leading into the period of the [[Cold War|Cold War]].
title: Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy

abstract: Tower 42 is a [[skyscraper|skyscraper]] in the [[City of London|City of London]], [[England|England]]. It is the fourth-tallest in the City and [[tenth-tallest|List of tallest buildings and structures in London]] in [[Greater London|Greater London]]. Its original name was the National Westminster Tower (commonly known as the NatWest Tower), having been built to house [[NatWest|National Westminster Bank]]'s international headquarters. Seen from above, the shape of the tower resembles that of the NatWest logo (three [[chevrons|Chevron (insignia)]] in a hexagonal arrangement).
title: Tower 42

abstract: Sanchi is the center of a region with a number of stupas, all within a few miles of Sanchi, including [[Satdhara|Satdhara]] (9   km to the W of Sanchi, 40 stupas, the [[Relics of Sariputra and Mahamoggallana|Relics of Sariputra and Mahamoggallana]], now enshrined in the new Vihara, were unearthed there), [[Bhojpur|Bhojpur Stupas]] (also called Morel Khurd, a fortified hilltop with 60 stupas) and [[Andher|Andher Stupas]] (respectively 11   km and 17   km SE of Sanchi), as well as [[Sonari|Sonari Stupa]] (10   km SW of Sanchi). Further south, about 100   km away, is [[Saru Maru|Saru Maru]]. [[Bharhut|Bharhut]] is 300   km to the northeast.
title: Sanchi

abstract: The Panthéon (, from [[Greek|Greek language]] πάνθειον (ἱερόν) '(temple) to all the gods') is a building in the [[Latin Quarter|Latin Quarter]] in [[Paris|Paris]], [[France|France]]. It was originally built as a church dedicated to [[St. Genevieve|Genevieve]] and to house the reliquary [[châsse|Chasse (casket)]] containing her relics but, after many changes, now functions as a secular [[mausoleum|mausoleum]] containing the remains of distinguished French citizens. It is an early example of [[neo-classicism|neo-classicism]], with a [[façade|façade]] modelled on the [[Pantheon in Rome|Pantheon, Rome]], surmounted by a [[dome|dome]] that owes some of its character to [[Bramante|Donato Bramante]]'s [[Tempietto|San Pietro in Montorio]]. Located in the [[5th arrondissement|5th arrondissement of Paris]] on the [[Montagne Sainte-Geneviève|Montagne Sainte-Geneviève]], the Panthéon looks out over all of Paris. Designer [[Jacques-Germain Soufflot|Jacques-Germain Soufflot]] had the intention of combining the lightness and brightness of the [[Gothic|Gothic architecture]] cathedral with classical principles, but its role as a mausoleum required the great Gothic windows to be blocked.
title: Panthéon

abstract: Constructed from 1887–1889 as the entrance to the [[1889 World's Fair|Exposition Universelle (1889)]], it was initially criticised by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design, but it has become a global [[cultural icon|cultural icon]] of France and one of the most recognisable structures in the world. The Eiffel Tower is the most-visited paid monument in the world; 6.91   million people ascended it in 2015.
title: Eiffel Tower

abstract: The CN Tower () is a [[concrete|concrete]] communications and observation [[tower|tower]] located in [[Downtown|Downtown Toronto]] [[Toronto|Toronto]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada. Built on the former [[Railway Lands|Railway Lands]], it was completed in 1976. Its name "CN" originally referred to [[Canadian National|Canadian National Railway]], the railway company that built the tower. Following the railway's decision to [[divest|Divestment]] non-core freight railway assets prior to the company's [[privatization|privatization]] in 1995, it transferred the tower to the [[Canada Lands Company|Canada Lands Company]], a federal [[Crown corporation|Crown corporations of Canada]] responsible for real estate development.
title: CN Tower

abstract: Walmer Lifeboat Station was established in 1830. Over two thousand ships are believed to have been wrecked on the [[Goodwin Sands|Goodwin Sands]], and the masts of several wrecks are visible from the shore at low tide. Hence there have always been two lifeboats located at the [[joined towns|conurbation]] of [[Deal|Deal, Kent]] and [[Walmer|Walmer]] along the coast opposite the sands.
title: Walmer Lifeboat Station

abstract: Tenby Lifeboat Station is a [[lifeboat|lifeboat (rescue)]] station in [[Tenby|Tenby]], [[Pembrokeshire|Pembrokeshire]], Wales that has been situated to the east of the town since 1852, three generations having been built; the original and updates in 1905 and 2005. The station currently houses two lifeboats.
title: Tenby Lifeboat Station

abstract: Broadcasting House is the [[headquarters|headquarters]] of the [[BBC|BBC]], in [[Portland Place|Portland Place]] and [[Langham Place, London|Langham Place, London]]. The first radio broadcast from the building was made on 15 March 1932, and the building was officially opened two months later, on 15 May. The main building is in [[Art Deco|Art Deco]] style, with a facing of [[Portland stone|Portland stone]] over a [[steel frame|steel frame]]. It is a [[Grade II* listed building|Listed building]] and includes the BBC Radio Theatre, where music and speech programmes are recorded in front of a studio audience, and the lobby that was used as a location for filming the 1998 BBC television series In the Red.
title: Broadcasting House

abstract: The IDS Center is an office skyscraper located at 80 South 8th Street in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota|Minnesota]]. Completed in 1972, it is the [[tallest building in Minneapolis|List of tallest buildings in Minneapolis]], and the [[tallest building in the state|List of tallest buildings in Minnesota]] at a height of . It originally stood , though a garage for window washing equipment was added between 1978 and 1979. The structure rises to when including communications spires on the roof, indisputably the highest points in the city. The IDS was constructed as the headquarters of Investors Diversified Services, Inc.—now [[Ameriprise Financial|Ameriprise Financial]]. It also housed the headquarters of Dayton Hudson Corporation (now [[Target Corporation|Target Corporation]]) from 1972 until 2001.The complex consists of five parts: the 57-story IDS Tower itself at 8th Street & Nicollet Mall, an 8-story annex building along Marquette Avenue, the 19-story Marquette Hotel at 7th Street & Marquette Avenue, and a 2-story retail building that was originally dominated by [[Woolworth's|F. W. Woolworth Company]]. These four buildings are joined by the 7-story Crystal Court.
title: IDS Center

abstract: Construction of Lakhta Center started on 30 October 2012; it was topped out on 29 January 2018. The Lakhta Center surpassed Vostok Tower of the [[Federation Towers|Federation Tower]] in Moscow as the tallest building in Russia and Europe on 5 October 2017. The center is designed for large-scale [[mixed-use development|mixed-use development]]: composing of public facilities and offices. The building was designed by Tony Kettle, author of the design, while at [[RMJM|RMJM]]. The project was then continued by GORPROJECT (2011-2017) based on the RMJM Concept (2011) under the main contractor, [[Rönesans Holding|Rönesans Holding]]. The Lakhta Center is intended to become the new headquarters of Russian energy company [[Gazprom|Gazprom]].
title: Lakhta Center

abstract: The Digital Media City Landmark Building () or DMC Landmark Building, also known as Seoul Lite or Light Tower, was a 133-floor, [[supertall|supertall]] [[skyscraper|skyscraper]] proposed for construction in [[Digital Media City|Digital Media City]], [[Seoul|Seoul]], [[South Korea|South Korea]]. It was slated to become the [[third-tallest|List of tallest buildings in the world]] building in the world when completed, after [[Burj Khalifa|Burj Khalifa]] and [[Pingan International Finance Centre|Pingan International Finance Centre]]. It would have been the tallest building in [[Korea|Korea]]. Construction broke ground on 16 October 2009, and was scheduled to be completed and ready for occupancy by April 2015. It was to be built with the country's own capital and technology at an estimated cost of 3.3 trillion [[won|South Korean won]] (US$2.9 billion).
title: Seoul Lite

abstract: The Palace of Moncloa or Moncloa Palace () is the [[official residence|official residence]] and workplace of the [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister of Spain]]. It is located in Puerta de Hierro Avenue, in the [[Moncloa-Aravaca|Moncloa-Aravaca]] district in [[Madrid|Madrid]]. It has been the official residence of the [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister of Spain]] since 1977, when [[Adolfo Suárez|Adolfo Suárez]] moved the residence from the [[Palace of Villamejor|Palace of Villamejor]].
title: Palace of Moncloa

abstract: 122 Leadenhall Street, also known as the Leadenhall Building is a [[skyscraper|skyscraper]] in [[London|London]] that is tall. It opened in July 2014 and was designed by [[Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners|Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners]]; it is known informally as The Cheesegrater because of its distinctive wedge shape similar to that of the [[kitchen utensil|kitchen utensil]] with the [[same name|grater]]. It is one of a number of tall buildings recently completed or under construction in the [[City of London|City of London]] financial district, including [[20 Fenchurch Street|20 Fenchurch Street]], [[The Pinnacle|The Pinnacle (London)]], and [[The Scalpel|The Scalpel]].
title: 122 Leadenhall Street

abstract: Partnership House is a landmark tower office building in [[Gosforth|Gosforth]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]]. It is located within the [[Regent Centre|Regent Centre]] business park, and was originally built to act as the main entrance and landmark building within the headquarters complex of the [[Northern Rock|Northern Rock]] bank, prior to its near-collapse and [[nationalisation|nationalisation]]. It lies in the [[West Gosforth|West Gosforth]] council ward. The building is owned by the [[local council|Local government in the United Kingdom]], [[Newcastle City Council|Newcastle City Council]], whereas the majority of the Regent Centre buildings are owned by the Fordgate Group.
title: Partnership House

abstract: At ten times larger than BBC Wales existing site at [[Llandaff|Llandaff]], the Doctor Who residency at Upper Boat Studios included the use of its six sound stages. Other facilities at Upper Boat included a large [[props|theatrical property]] store, workshops, and [[video edit|video editing]] suites.
title: Upper Boat Studios

abstract: Sheringham Lifeboat Station is an RNLI operated lifeboat station located in the town of [[Sheringham|Sheringham]] in the English county of [[Norfolk|Norfolk]]. Since 1992, the station has been inshore operations only - currently with an [[Atlantic 85 rigid inflatable|Atlantic 85 class lifeboat]] - offshore lifeboats are to the east at [[Cromer|Cromer Lifeboat Station]] and the west at [[Wells-next-the-sea|Wells-next-the-Sea Lifeboat Station]].
title: Sheringham Lifeboat Station

abstract: Wells-next-the-Sea Lifeboat Station is an [[RNLI|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] operated [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] station located in the town of [[Wells-next-the-Sea|Wells-next-the-Sea]] in the English county of [[Norfolk|Norfolk]]. The station operates both inshore and offshore lifeboats. The inshore boat is called and is a lifeboat, whilst the offshore boat is called , and is a [[Mersey class lifeboat|Mersey class lifeboat]]. The station boathouse is located at the beach on the western side of [[Wells Harbour|Wells Harbour]] mouth.
title: Wells-next-the-Sea Lifeboat Station

abstract: The Gliwice Radio Tower is tall (including the long spire on its top), with a wooden framework of impregnated [[larch|larch]] linked by brass connectors. It was nicknamed "the Silesian [[Eiffel Tower|Eiffel Tower]]" by the local population. The tower has four platforms, which are 40.4 m, 55.3 m, 80.0 m and 109.7 m above ground. The top platform measures 2.13 x 2.13 m. A ladder with 365 steps provides access to the top.
title: Gliwice Radio Tower

abstract: Gulf Tower is a 44-story, [[Art Deco|Art Deco]] skyscraper in [[downtown Pittsburgh|downtown Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania|Pennsylvania]]. The tower is one of the major distinctive and recognizable features of the city and is named for the [[ Gulf Oil Corporation|Gulf Oil]], which was one of the leading multinational oil companies of its time, consistently ranking among the largest 10 corporations in the country. In 1984, Gulf and [[Chevron|Chevron Corporation]] took part in the world's largest merger ($13.3 billion or $ billion today) to that time.
title: Gulf Tower

abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco (informally referred to as the San Francisco Fed) is the [[federal bank|Federal Reserve]] for the twelfth district in the [[United States|United States]]. The twelfth district is made up of nine western [[states|U.S. state]]—[[Alaska|Alaska]], [[Arizona|Arizona]], [[California|California]], [[Hawaii|Hawaii]], [[Idaho|Idaho]], [[Nevada|Nevada]], [[Oregon|Oregon]], [[Utah|Utah]], and [[Washington|Washington (U.S. state)]]—plus the [[Northern Mariana Islands|Northern Mariana Islands]], [[American Samoa|American Samoa]], and [[Guam|Guam]]. The San Francisco Fed has branch offices in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], [[Portland|Portland, Oregon]], [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City, Utah]], and [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]]. It also has a cash processing center in [[Phoenix|Phoenix, Arizona]].The twelfth district is the nation's largest by area and population, covering , or 36% of the nation's area, and 60 million people. The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco is the second-largest by assets held, after [[New York|Federal Reserve Bank of New York]]. In 2004 the San Francisco Fed processed 20.8 billion [[currency|currency]] notes and 1.5 billion commercial checks.
title: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco

abstract: On 6 May 1945, the German general [[Blaskowitz|Johannes Blaskowitz]] surrendered to the Canadian general [[Charles Foulkes|Charles Foulkes (Canadian)]], which ended the Second World War in the Netherlands. The Generals negotiated the terms of surrender in the Hotel de Wereld.
title: Hotel de Wereld

abstract: Absolute World is a [[residential condominium|Residential condominiums in Canada]] twin tower skyscraper complex in the five tower Absolute City Centre development in [[Mississauga|Mississauga]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada. The project was built by Fernbrook Homes and Cityzen Development Group. With the first three towers completed (Absolute City Centre 1 and 2 and Absolute Vision), the last two towers (Absolute World 4 and 5) were topped off at 50 and 56 [[storey|storeys]].
title: Absolute World

abstract: Zagreb TV Tower (or Sljeme transmitter) is a 169-metre (563   ft) tall TV and radio tower built of [[reinforced concrete|reinforced concrete]] on the summit of the 1035 metre (3450   ft) tall peak Sljeme of the [[Medvednica|Medvednica]] mountain north of [[Zagreb|Zagreb]], [[Croatia|Croatia]].
title: Zagreb TV Tower

abstract: One Kansas City Place is the tallest building in the [[U.S. state|United States]] of [[Missouri|Missouri]]. It is located in [[Downtown|Downtown Kansas City]] [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City, Missouri]], bounded by 12th Street to the north, Baltimore Avenue to the west, and Main Street to the east. Built in 1988, this skyscraper was designed by [[Patty Berkebile Nelson & Immenschuh|BNIM#Patty Berkebile Nelson & Immenschuh]] and replaced the [[Town Pavilion|Town Pavilion]] as the city's tallest building.
title: One Kansas City Place

abstract: Western Canadian Place is an office tower complex in [[Calgary|Calgary]], [[Alberta|Alberta]], [[Canada|Canada]]. It consists of two buildings, the taller North Tower and the shorter South Tower.
title: Western Canadian Place

abstract: Simulations Canada is the name of a Canadian board [[wargame|Wargaming]] publisher established in Nova Scotia in 1977. The company was founded by Stephen Newberg as a one-man operation and was one of only a handful of companies devoted to publishing wargames at that time. Other companies such as [[Avalon Hill|Avalon Hill]] and [[Simulations Publications|Simulations Publications]], Inc. did not accept unsolicited submissions, resulting in the creation of the company.
title: Simulations Canada

abstract: Kay Musical Instrument Company was a [[musical instrument|musical instrument]] manufacturer of the United States, in operation from the 1930s until the 1960s.
title: Kay Musical Instrument Company

abstract: Anderson Valley Brewing Company is a [[brewery|brewery]] founded in 1987 in [[Boonville|Boonville, California]], [[California|California]]. Its name is derived from its [[Anderson Valley|Anderson Valley]] location in [[Mendocino County|Mendocino County, California]].
title: Anderson Valley Brewing Company

abstract: Great Lakes Brewing Company is a [[brewery|brewery]] and [[brewpub|brewpub]] in [[Cleveland|Cleveland]], [[Ohio|Ohio]]. The first brewpub and [[microbrewery|microbrewery]] in the state, Great Lakes Brewing has been noted as important to Cleveland's local identity and as one of the initial forces behind the revival of the [[Ohio City|Ohio City, Cleveland]] neighborhood on the near West Side. In 2015, it was the 21st-largest craft brewery by volume and the 28th-largest overall brewery in the [[United States|United States]]. The company was established in 1988 by brothers Patrick and Daniel Conway, both St. Edward High School graduates, in Cleveland's Ohio City neighborhood, located near [[St. Ignatius High School|Saint Ignatius High School (Cleveland, Ohio)]] and the [[West Side Market|West Side Market]]. The brewpub and restaurant remain in their original locations, while production has expanded to adjacent properties.
title: Great Lakes Brewing Company

abstract: MacGillivray Freeman Films is an [[American|United States]] [[film studio|film studio]] based in [[Laguna Beach|Laguna Beach]], [[California|California]] and founded in the mid-1960s by [[Greg MacGillivray|Greg MacGillivray]] and Jim Freeman. It has produced over 40 documentaries, feature films, and [[IMAX|IMAX]] films.
title: MacGillivray Freeman Films

abstract: F1 in Schools is an international STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) competition for school children (aged 11–18), in which groups of 3–6 students have to design and manufacture a miniature car out of the official F1 Model Block using [[CAD|Computer-aided design]]/[[CAM|Computer-aided manufacturing]] design tools. The cars are powered by CO2 cartridges and are attached to a track by a nylon wire. They are timed from the moment they are launched to when they pass the finish line by a computer.The cars have to follow extensive regulations, in a similar fashion to Formula 1 (e.g. the wheels of the car must be in contact with the track at all times). The cars are raced on a 20m long track with two lanes, to allow two cars to be raced simultaneously. Software called F1 Virtual Wind Tunnel was designed specifically for the challenge. F1 Virtual Wind Tunnel or F1 VWT uses [[computational fluid dynamics|computational fluid dynamics]] (CFD) to simulate air resistance on the "cars" made in the [[CAD|Computer-aided design]].
title: F1 in Schools

abstract: The notable employees of the Buy More fit into three categories: management, Nerd Herd (technical support), and sales associates (who are called "Green Shirts" on account of their uniforms). Current and recent notable employees are listed by their last held position.
title: Buy More

abstract: The Mexican Council on Foreign Relations (COMEXI; ) was established the November 22, 2001. So far, it is the only plural and multidisciplinary forum, focused in the debate and analysis of Mexico's role in the world and the growing influence of international events on the national agenda. The Council is a civic association, nonprofit and independent of government. It is financed entirely by its members' contributions
title: Mexican Council on Foreign Relations

abstract: Glimcher Realty Trust was a [[real estate investment trust|real estate investment trust]] based in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus, Ohio]] that invested in [[shopping mall|shopping malls]]. In 2015, the company was acquired by [[Washington Prime Group|Washington Prime Group]].
title: Glimcher Realty Trust

abstract: Cromemco was a [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View, California]] [[microcomputer|microcomputer]] company known for its high-end [[Z80|Zilog Z80]]-based [[S-100 bus|S-100 bus]] computers and peripherals in the early days of the personal computer revolution.
title: Cromemco

abstract: Slazenger () is an English [[sporting goods|sporting goods]] manufacturer which concentrates on racket sports including tennis, golf, cricket and hockey. Founded in 1881, it is one of the oldest surviving sporting brand names. It has the longest sporting sponsorship in world history, thanks to its association with the Wimbledon Tennis Championship, providing balls for the tournament since 1902.
title: Slazenger

abstract: The House of Guerlain was owned and managed by members of the Guerlain family from its inception in 1828 to 1994. It was acquired in 1994 by the [[LVMH|LVMH]] group, a French multinational investment corporation specializing in luxury brands.
title: Guerlain

abstract: Hawaiian Falls Waterparks is a chain of [[waterpark|waterparks]] operated by ProParks Management Company. Hawaiian Falls parks are all built using the public-private partnership model, where cities contribute funds and/or other incentives and the parks are built on public land. Each of the seven parks has a separate lease structure with the cities participation ranging from contributing land and infrastructure costs(Garland and The Colony)to 100% financing . The first two parks were in the City of Garland and the City of The Colony, both in Texas. The third park was located in the South Oak Cliff neighborhood of Dallas. In 2004 Hawaiian Falls experienced financial problems and founder and CEO David Busch sold the company to Herschend Family Entertainment. In 2006 Busch was able to buy the company back from Herschend after purchasing, then reselling The Colony and Garland Parks to CNL Lifestyle Properties. In addition to paying rent to Garland and The Colony, Hawaiian Falls must pay rent to CNL. In 2014 The City of Garland conducted an audit of Hawaiian Falls and was unable to verify Hawaiian Falls gross receipts for the 2011 season. The audit stated that Hawaiian Falls "could not provide source documentation for group ticket sales, group food and beverage sales, season pass sales and online ticket sales."
title: Hawaiian Falls

abstract: Brompton Bicycle is a British manufacturer of [[folding bicycle|folding bicycles]] based in [[Greenford|Greenford]], London..
title: Brompton Bicycle

abstract: Norddeutsche Automobil und Motoren GmbH (North German Automobile and Engines) was a German automobile manufacturer, created in 1908 and owned by the [[Norddeutscher Lloyd|Norddeutscher Lloyd]] shipping company. The factory was in [[Bremen|Bremen (city)]]. Many of the products of the company and its successors were badged with the Lloyd marque.
title: North German Automobile and Engine

abstract: Former [[Columbia Pictures Entertainment|Sony Pictures]] chairman Victor A. Kaufman became chairman and chief executive officer of Savoy Pictures in 1992 along with vice chairman executive, Lewis J. Korman. Kaufman has claimed that the name came from the Savoy Special bat [[Robert Redford|Robert Redford]]'s character used in [[The Natural|The Natural (film)]]. Savoy intended to finance and distribute films in the $12–25 million range, investing in up to $15 million per film. In June of that year, Savoy entered into a deal with [[HBO|HBO]] for the home video, pay-TV, and pay-per-view rights to its films.
title: Savoy Pictures

abstract: In January 1999, AJPW founder and promoter [[Giant Baba|Giant Baba]] died, leaving the company in the hands of his widow Motoko Baba as owner and Misawa as president. However, disheartened with Motoko Baba's proposed direction for the company, Misawa departed the promotion on May 28, 2000 to form a new promotion called Pro Wrestling Noah. All but two native stars ([[Masanobu Fuchi|Masanobu Fuchi]] and [[Toshiaki Kawada|Toshiaki Kawada]]) and two [[gaijin|gaijin]] ([[Stan Hansen|Stan Hansen]] and [[Maunakea Mossman|Maunakea Mossman]]) followed Misawa. The promotion's name alludes to the Biblical story of [[Noah|Noah]], in which the people and animals in the ark survive the flood and make a new beginning in the world, a story which was seen as a parallel to the wrestlers' departure from AJPW. Noah's promotional symbol, an ark with a dove holding an olive branch, refers to this.
title: Pro Wrestling Noah

abstract: Flying Fish Brewing Company is a [[craft brewery|craft brewery]] based in [[Somerdale|Somerdale, New Jersey]], [[New Jersey|New Jersey]]. Founded in 1995 in [[Cherry Hill|Cherry Hill, New Jersey]], it moved to its Somerdale location in 2012. It is today the largest brewery in New Jersey.
title: Flying Fish Brewing

abstract: Picturehouse Cinemas is a network of cinemas in the United Kingdom, operated by Picturehouse Cinemas Ltd and owned by [[Cineworld|Cineworld]]. The company runs its own film distribution arm, Picturehouse Entertainment, which has released acclaimed films such as [[David Lowery's|David Lowery (director)]] [[A Ghost Story|A Ghost Story]], [[Sally Potter|Sally Potter]]'s [[The Party|The_Party_(2017_film)]] and Francis Lee's [[God's Own Country|God's Own Country (2017 film)]] and will release upcoming films Custody and The Wife. A previous iteration of this distribution arm, which focused largely on alternative content, was sold in 2017 to [[Howard Panter|Howard Panter]] and [[Rosemary Squire|Rosemary Squire]] and rebranded Trafalgar Releasing.
title: Picturehouse Cinemas

abstract: Trimurti Films Pvt. Ltd. was an [[India|Indian]] film production house founded by [[Gulshan Rai|Gulshan Rai]] in 1970. After Rai's death, his son [[Rajiv Rai|Rajiv Rai]] took over as the head of the company. The company's maiden production [[Johny Mera Naam|Johny Mera Naam]] (1970) emerged a smash ht and went on to celebrate Golden Jubilee. The company subsequently produced notable blockbusters like [[Deewaar|Deewaar]], [[Trishul|Trishul (film)e]], [[Vidhaata|Vidhaata]], [[Tridev|Tridev]], [[Vishwatma|Vishwatma]], [[Mohra|Mohra]] and [[Gupt|Gupt]].
title: Trimurti Films

abstract: Interscope Communications was founded in 1982 by media mogul [[Ted Field|Ted Field]], who aimed to create films with mass appeal. Field acted as a [[producer|Film producer]] or [[executive producer|executive producer]] on a number of films in Interscope's filmography. The company’s first film, [[Revenge of the Nerds|Revenge of the Nerds]], was released in 1984 and was a box office success. That same year, [[Robert W. Cort|Robert W. Cort]], a former executive of [[20th Century Fox|20th Century Fox]] and [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia Pictures]], joined Interscope and became the president of the company. Cort also co-produced a number of films.
title: Interscope Communications

abstract: Carlton & United Breweries (CUB Pty. Ltd.) is an [[Australia|Australian]] brewing company. It is based in [[Abbotsford|Abbotsford, Victoria]], a suburb of [[Melbourne|Melbourne]], [[Victoria|Victoria (Australia)]]. In 1983 it became a [[wholly owned subsidiary|wholly owned subsidiary]] of [[Elders IXL|Elders IXL]] and CUB was delisted. In 1990, Elders IXL was renamed as [[Foster's Group|Foster's Group]], and in July 2004, CUB changed its name to Carlton & United Beverages. In February 2009, Foster's announced the decision to separate the Australian Wine division from the Australian Beer, Cider & Spirits (BCS) division, and rename BCS to Carlton & United Breweries.
title: Carlton & United Breweries

abstract: O.S.C.A. (Officine Specializzate Costruzione Automobili—Fratelli Maserati S.p.A.) was an [[Italian|Italy]] manufacturer of [[racing|Racing car]] and [[sports car|sports cars]] established 1947 in [[San Lazzaro di Savena|San Lazzaro di Savena]], [[Bologna|Province of Bologna]], by the [[Maserati brothers|Maserati brothers]], and closed down in 1967. Its name is usually abbreviated to OSCA or Osca.
title: O.S.C.A.

abstract: The Stroh Brewery Company was a [[beer|beer]] [[brewery|brewery]] located in [[Detroit|Detroit]], [[Michigan|Michigan]], United States. In addition to its own Stroh's brand, the company produced or bought the rights to several other brands including [[Goebel|Goebel Brewing Company]], [[Schaefer|Schaefer Beer]], [[Schlitz|Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company]], Augsburger, Erlanger, [[Old Style|Pabst Brewing Company#Old Style]], [[Lone Star|Pabst Brewing Company#Lone Star]], [[Old Milwaukee|Old Milwaukee]], Red River, and Signature, as well as manufacturing [[Stroh's Ice Cream|Stroh's Ice Cream]]. The company was taken over and broken up in 2000, but some of its brands continued to be made by the new owners. The Stroh's brand is currently owned and marketed by [[Pabst Brewing Company|Pabst Brewing Company]], except in Canada where the Stroh brands are owned by [[Sleeman Breweries|Sleeman Breweries]].
title: Stroh Brewery Company

abstract: Hahn Brewery is a brewery that was established by Dr Charles "Chuck" Hahn in 1988 at an old factory site in the suburb of [[Camperdown|Camperdown, New South Wales]] in [[Sydney|Sydney]], [[New South Wales|New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]].
title: Hahn Brewery

abstract: The Autonomous Republic of Crimea (, Avtonomna Respublika Krym; , Avtonomnaya Respublika Krym; , Къырым Мухтар Джумхуриети, Ҡырым Мухтар Җумхуриети), an [[autonomous republic|autonomous republic]] of [[Ukraine|Ukraine]] encompassing most of [[Crimea|Crimea]], was [[annexed|Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation]] by the [[Russian Federation|Russian Federation]] in 2014.
title: Autonomous Republic of Crimea

abstract: The Nordic countries or the Nordics are a geographical and cultural [[region|region]] in [[Northern Europe|Northern Europe]] and the [[North Atlantic|Atlantic Ocean]], where they are most commonly known as Norden (literally "the North"). The term includes [[Denmark|Denmark]], [[Finland|Finland]], [[Iceland|Iceland]], [[Norway|Norway]], and [[Sweden|Sweden]], as well as [[Greenland|Greenland]] and the [[Faroe Islands|Faroe Islands]] — which are both part of the Kingdom of Denmark — and the [[Åland Islands|Åland Islands]] and [[Svalbard and Jan Mayen|Svalbard and Jan Mayen]] — archipelagos that belong to Finland and Norway respectively., whereas the [[Norwegian Antarctic territories|Norwegian Antarctic territories]]  are often not considered a part of the Nordic countries, due to their geographical location. [[Scandinavians|North Germanic peoples]], who comprise over three quarters of the region's population, are the largest group, followed by [[Finns|Finns]], who comprise the majority in Finland; other groups are indigenous minorities such as the [[Greenlandic Inuit|Greenlandic Inuit]] and the [[Sami people|Sami people]], and recent immigrants and their descendants. The native languages [[Swedish|Swedish language]], [[Danish|Danish language]], [[Norwegian|Norwegian language]], [[Icelandic|Icelandic language]], and [[Faroese|Faroese language]] are all [[North Germanic languages|North Germanic languages]] rooted in [[Old Norse|Old Norse]]. Native non-Germanic languages are [[Finnish|Finnish language]], [[Greenlandic|Greenlandic language]] and several [[Sami languages|Sami languages]]. The main religion is [[Lutheran|Lutheran]] [[Christianity|Christianity]]. The Nordic countries have much in common in their way of life, [[history|History of Scandinavia]], religion, their use of [[Scandinavian languages|Scandinavian languages]] and [[social structure|Nordic model]]. The Nordic countries have a long history of political unions and other close relations, but do not form a separate entity today. The [[Scandinavist movement|Scandinavism]] sought to unite Denmark, Norway and Sweden into one country in the 19th century, with the indepedence of Finland in the early 20th century, and Iceland in the mid 20th century, this movement expanded into the modern organised Nordic cooperation which includes the [[Nordic Council|Nordic Council]] and the [[Nordic Council of Ministers|Nordic Council of Ministers]]. Especially in [[English|English language]], [[Scandinavia|Scandinavia]] is sometimes used as a synonym for the Nordic countries, but that term more properly refers to the three monarchies of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Geologically, the [[Scandinavian Peninsula|Scandinavian Peninsula]] comprises the mainland of Norway and Sweden as well as the northernmost part of Finland.
title: Nordic countries

abstract: Macedonia (; ), officially the Republic of Macedonia ( ), is a country in the [[Balkan Peninsula|Balkans]] in [[Southeast Europe|Southeast Europe]]. It is one of the [[successor states|succession of states]] of the former [[Yugoslavia|Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], from which it declared independence in 1991.
title: Republic of Macedonia

abstract: Austria (, ; ), officially the Republic of Austria (, ), is a country of nearly 9 million people in [[Central Europe|Central Europe]]. It is bordered by the [[Czech Republic|Czech Republic]] and [[Germany|Germany]] to the north, [[Hungary|Hungary]] and [[Slovakia|Slovakia]] to the east, [[Slovenia|Slovenia]] and [[Italy|Italy]] to the south, and [[Switzerland|Switzerland]] and [[Liechtenstein|Liechtenstein]] to the west. The territory of Austria covers . The terrain is highly mountainous, lying within the [[Alps|Alps]]; only 32% of the country is below , and its highest point is . The majority of the population speaks local [[Bavarian dialects|Bavarian language]] as their native language, and [[German|German language]] in its standard form is the country's [[official language|official language]]. Other local official languages are [[Hungarian|Hungarian language]], [[Burgenland Croatian|Burgenland Croatian]], and [[Slovene|Slovene language]].
title: Austria

abstract: Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha is a [[British Overseas Territory|British Overseas Territory]] located in the [[South Atlantic|South Atlantic]] and consisting of the island of [[Saint Helena|Saint Helena]], [[Ascension Island|Ascension Island]] and the [[archipelago|archipelago]] of [[Tristan da Cunha|Tristan da Cunha]].
title: Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha

abstract: Eritrea is a multi-ethnic country, with nine recognized ethnic groups in its population of around million. Most residents speak languages from the [[Afroasiatic|Afroasiatic languages]] family, either of the [[Ethiopian Semitic languages|Ethiopian Semitic languages]] or [[Cushitic|Cushitic languages]] branches. Among these communities, the [[Tigrinyas|Tigrayans]] make up about 55% of the population, with the [[Tigre people|Tigre people]] constituting around 30% of inhabitants. In addition, there are a number of [[Nilo-Saharan|Nilo-Saharan languages]]-speaking [[Nilotic|Nilotic]] ethnic minorities. Most people in the territory adhere to [[Christianity|Christianity]] or [[Islam|Islam]].
title: Eritrea

abstract: Guyana (pronounced or ), officially the Co-operative Republic of Guyana, is a country on the northern mainland of [[South America|South America]]. It is, however, often considered part of the [[Caribbean region|Caribbean]] because of its strong cultural, historical, and political ties with other [[Anglo-Caribbean|British West Indies]] countries and the [[Caribbean Community|Caribbean Community]] (CARICOM). Guyana is bordered by the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic Ocean]] to the north, [[Brazil|Brazil]] to the south and southwest, [[Venezuela|Venezuela]] to the west, and [[Suriname|Suriname]] to the east. With , Guyana is the third-smallest [[sovereign state|sovereign state]] on mainland South America after [[Uruguay|Uruguay]] and [[Suriname|Suriname]].
title: Guyana

abstract: Djibouti ( ; , , , , officially the Republic of Djibouti) is a country located in the [[Horn of Africa|Horn of Africa]]. It is bordered by [[Eritrea|Eritrea]] in the north, [[Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] in the west and south, and [[Somalia|Somalia]] in the southeast. The remainder of the border is formed by the [[Red Sea|Red Sea]] and the [[Gulf of Aden|Gulf of Aden]] at the east. Djibouti occupies a total area of .
title: Djibouti

abstract: South Africa, officially the Republic of South Africa (RSA), is the southernmost country in [[Africa|Africa]]. It is bounded to the south by of coastline of [[Southern Africa|Southern Africa]] stretching along the [[South Atlantic|South Atlantic]] and [[Indian Ocean|Indian Oceans]]; to the north by the neighbouring countries of [[Namibia|Namibia]], [[Botswana|Botswana]], and [[Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe]]; and to the east and northeast by [[Mozambique|Mozambique]] and [[Eswatini (Swaziland)|Eswatini]]; and it surrounds the [[enclaved country|Enclave and exclave]] of [[Lesotho|Lesotho]]. South Africa is the largest country in Southern Africa and the [[25th-largest country|List of countries and outlying territories by total area]] in the world by land area and, with over [[57 million people|Demographics of South Africa]], is the world's [[24th-most populous nation|List of countries by population]]. It is the southernmost country on the mainland of the [[Old World|Old World]] or the [[Eastern Hemisphere|Eastern Hemisphere]]. About 80 percent of South Africans are of [[Sub-Saharan Africa|Sub-Saharan African]] ancestry, divided among a [[variety of ethnic groups|Ethnic groups in South Africa]] speaking [[different African languages|Languages of South Africa]], nine of which have official status. The remaining population consists of Africa's largest communities of [[European (White)|White South Africans]], [[Asian|Asian South Africans]] ([[Indian|Indian South Africans]]), and [[multiracial|multiracial]] ([[Coloured|Coloured]]) ancestry.
title: South Africa

abstract: Cape Verde () or Cabo Verde (, ) (, ), officially the Republic of Cabo Verde, is an [[island country|island country]] spanning an [[archipelago|archipelago]] of 10 [[volcanic islands|High island]] in the central [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic Ocean]]. It forms part of the [[Macaronesia|Macaronesia]] [[ecoregion|ecoregion]], along with the [[Azores|Azores]], [[Canary Islands|Canary Islands]], [[Madeira|Madeira]], and the [[Savage Isles|Savage Isles]]. In ancient times these islands were referred to as "the Islands of the Blessed" or the "Fortunate Isles". Located west of the [[Cape Verde Peninsula|Cape Verde Peninsula]] in [[West Africa|West Africa]], the islands cover a combined area of slightly over .
title: Cape Verde

abstract: Mauritania is a country in [[Northwest Africa|Northwest Africa]]. It is the eleventh largest [[sovereign state|sovereign state]] in [[Africa|Africa]] and is bordered by the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic Ocean]] to the west, [[Western Sahara|Western Sahara]] to the north and northwest, [[Algeria|Algeria]] to the northeast, [[Mali|Mali]] to the east and southeast, and [[Senegal|Senegal]] to the southwest.
title: Mauritania

abstract: The Collectivity of Saint Martin (), commonly known as simply Saint Martin (), is an [[overseas collectivity of France|overseas collectivity of France]] in the West Indies in the [[Caribbean|Caribbean]]. With a population of 36,286 (as of January 2011) on an area of , it encompasses the northern 60% of the [[divided island|divided island]] of [[Saint Martin|Saint Martin]], and some neighbouring [[islet|islets]], the largest of which is [[Île Tintamarre|Île Tintamarre]]. The southern 40% of the island of Saint Martin constitutes [[Sint Maarten|Sint Maarten]], since 2010 a [[constituent country|Countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands]] of the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Kingdom of the Netherlands]].
title: Collectivity of Saint Martin

abstract: Sint Maarten () is an [[island country|island country]] in the [[Caribbean|Caribbean]]. It is a [[constituent country|Countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands]] of the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Kingdom of the Netherlands]]. With a population of 40,120 on an area of , it encompasses the southern 40% of the [[divided island|divided island]] of [[Saint Martin|Saint Martin]], while the northern 60% of the island constitutes the French [[overseas collectivity|overseas collectivity]] of [[Saint-Martin|Collectivity of Saint Martin]]. Sint Maarten's [[capital|Capital city]] is [[Philipsburg|Philipsburg, Sint Maarten]].
title: Sint Maarten

abstract: Tyrol (; historically the Tyrole; ; ) is a historical region in the [[Alps|Alps]]; in northern [[Italy|Italy]] and western [[Austria|Austria]]. The area was to [[Habsburg times|Habsburg Monarchy]] the former [[County of Tyrol|County of Tyrol]]. The [[Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye|Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)]] in 1919 divided the area into two parts:
title: Tyrol

abstract: The Gambia is situated on either side of the [[Gambia River|Gambia River]], the nation's namesake, which flows through the centre of the Gambia and empties into the Atlantic Ocean. It has an area of with a population of 1,857,181 as of the April 2013 census. [[Banjul|Banjul]] is the Gambian capital and the largest cities are [[Serekunda|Serekunda]] and [[Brikama|Brikama]].
title: The Gambia

abstract: Nepal (; ), officially the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal ( ), is a [[landlocked|landlocked]] country in [[South Asia|South Asia]]. It is located mainly in the [[Himalaya|Himalayas]] but also includes parts of the [[Indo-Gangetic Plain|Indo-Gangetic Plain]]. With an estimated population of 26.4 million, it is 48th largest country by population and [[93rd largest country|List of countries by area]] by area. It borders [[China|China]] in the north and [[India|India]] in the south, east, and west while [[Bangladesh|Bangladesh]] is located within only 27   km (17   mi) of its southeastern tip and [[Bhutan|Bhutan]] is separated from it by the Indian state of [[Sikkim|Sikkim]]. Nepal has a [[diverse geography|Geography of Nepal]], including [[fertile plains|Terai]], subalpine forested hills, and eight of the world's ten [[tallest mountains|List of highest mountains#List]], including [[Mount Everest|Mount Everest]], the highest point on Earth. [[Kathmandu|Kathmandu]] is the nation's capital and largest city. Nepal is a multiethnic nation with [[Nepali|Nepali language]] as the official language.
title: Nepal

abstract: Republika Srpska (; , ; literally "Serb Republic") is one of two constitutional and legal [[entities|Political divisions of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia and Herzegovina]], the other being the [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. The entities are largely autonomous. Its de jure capital city is [[Sarajevo|Sarajevo]], but the de facto capital and [[administrative centre|administrative centre]] is [[Banja Luka|Banja Luka]].
title: Republika Srpska

abstract: Cambodia gained independence in 1953. The [[Vietnam War|Vietnam War]] extended into the country with the US bombing of Cambodia from [[1969|Operation Menu]] until [[1973|Operation Freedom Deal]]. Following the [[Cambodian coup of 1970|Cambodian coup of 1970]] which installed the right-wing pro-US [[Khmer Republic|Khmer Republic]], the deposed king gave his support to his former enemies, the [[Khmer Rouge|Khmer Rouge]]. The Khmer Rouge emerged as a major power, taking Phnom Penh in 1975 and later carrying out the [[Cambodian genocide|Cambodian genocide]] from 1975 until 1979, when they were ousted by Vietnam and the Vietnamese-backed [[People's Republic of Kampuchea|People's Republic of Kampuchea]], supported by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union]] in the [[Cambodian–Vietnamese War|Cambodian–Vietnamese War]] (1979–91). Following the [[1991 Paris Peace Accords|1991 Paris Peace Accords]], Cambodia was governed briefly by a [[United Nations mission|United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia]] (1992–93). The UN withdrew after [[holding elections|Cambodian general election, 1993]] in which around 90 percent of the registered voters cast ballots. The [[1997 factional fighting|1997 clashes in Cambodia]] resulted in the ousting of the government by Prime Minister [[Hun Sen|Hun Sen]] and the [[Cambodian People's Party|Cambodian People's Party]], who remain in power .
title: Cambodia

abstract: The Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic (, ) is a [[landlocked|landlocked country]] [[exclave|Enclave and exclave]] of the [[Republic of Azerbaijan|Azerbaijan]]. The region covers with a population of 410,000, bordering [[Armenia|Armenia]] (border ) to the east and north, [[Iran|Iran]] (border ) to the south and west, and [[Turkey|Turkey]] (border ) to the northwest.
title: Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic

abstract: Gagauzia or Gagauz Yeri ( or ; ; , Gagauzija), officially the Autonomous Territorial Unit of Gagauzia (; ; , ), is an [[autonomous region|Autonomous area]] of [[Moldova|Moldova]]. Its name comes from the [[Gagauz people|Gagauz people]]. Gagauz Yeri literally means "place of the Gagauz".
title: Gagauzia

abstract: Solomon Islands is a [[sovereign state|sovereign state]] consisting of six major islands and over 900 smaller islands in [[Oceania|Oceania]] lying to the east of [[Papua New Guinea|Papua New Guinea]] and northwest of [[Vanuatu|Vanuatu]] and covering a land area of . The country's capital, [[Honiara|Honiara]], is located on the island of [[Guadalcanal|Guadalcanal]]. The country takes its name from [[the Solomon Islands archipelago|Solomon Islands (archipelago)]], which is a collection of [[Melanesia|Melanesian]] islands that also includes the [[North Solomon Islands|North Solomon Islands]] (part of Papua New Guinea), but excludes outlying islands, such as [[Rennell and Bellona|Rennell and Bellona Province]], and the [[Santa Cruz Islands|Santa Cruz Islands]].
title: Solomon Islands

abstract: In Croatian, the term županija (county) is used, while in [[Bosnian|Bosnian language]] and [[Serbian|Serbian language]] the term is kanton/кантон. The canton is officially referred by the [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina|Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] as Canton 10/County 10 (Kanton 10 or Županija 10). The local government, however, refers to it as the [[Herzeg-Bosnia|Herzeg-Bosnia]] County (Hercegbosanska županija) and uses that name in the local constitution. Other names used at the national level include North Herzegovina Canton/County (Sjevernohercegovački kanton, Sjevernohercegovačka županija) and Livno Canton (Livanjski kanton), after its capital.
title: Canton 10

abstract: Territories of the United States are sub-national [[administrative divisions|administrative divisions]] directly overseen by the [[United States Federal Government|United States Federal Government]]. Unlike [[U.S. state|U.S. states]] and [[Native American tribes|Native Americans in the United States]] which exercise limited [[sovereignty|sovereignty]] alongside the federal government, territories are without sovereignty. The territories are classified by whether they are [[incorporated|#Incorporated and unincorporated territories]] and whether they have an "organized" government through an [[Organic Act|Organic Act]] passed by the [[U.S. Congress|United States Congress]].
title: Territories of the United States

abstract: The Dominican Republic (; ) is a country located in the island of [[Hispaniola|Hispaniola]], in the [[Greater Antilles|Greater Antilles]] archipelago of the [[Caribbean|Caribbean]] region. It occupies the eastern five-eighths of the island, which it shares with the nation of [[Haiti|Haiti]], making Hispaniola one of two Caribbean islands, along with [[Saint Martin|Saint Martin]], that are shared by two [[sovereign state|sovereign states]]. The Dominican Republic is the second-largest Caribbean nation by area (after [[Cuba|Cuba]]) at , and third by population with approximately 10 million people, of which approximately three million live in the metropolitan area of Santo Domingo, the capital city.
title: Dominican Republic

abstract: Colombia has been inhabited by various [[indigenous peoples|Indigenous peoples in Colombia]] since 12,000 BCE, including the [[Muisca|Muisca]], [[Quimbaya|Quimbaya civilization]], and the [[Tairona|Tairona]]. The Spanish arrived in 1499 and by the mid-16th century [[conquered and colonized|Spanish conquest of the Muisca]] much of the region, establishing the [[New Kingdom of Granada|New Kingdom of Granada]], with [[Santafé de Bogotá|Bogotá]] as its capital. [[Independence|Spanish American wars of independence]] from [[Spain|Spain]] was achieved in 1819, but by 1830 the "[[Gran Colombia|Gran Colombia]]" Federation was dissolved, with what is now Colombia and Panama emerging as the [[Republic of New Granada|Republic of New Granada]]. The new nation experimented with federalism as the [[Granadine Confederation|Granadine Confederation]] (1858), and then the [[United States of Colombia|United States of Colombia]] (1863), before the Republic of Colombia was finally declared in 1886. [[Panama seceded|Separation of Panama from Colombia]] in 1903, leading to Colombia's present borders. Beginning in the 1960s, the country suffered from an asymmetric low-intensity [[armed conflict|Colombian armed conflict (1964–present)]] and rampant political violence, both of which escalated in the 1990s. Since 2005, there has been significant improvement in security, stability, and rule of law.
title: Colombia

abstract: A Patch of Blue is a 1965 American drama film directed by [[Guy Green|Guy Green (filmmaker)]] about the relationship between a black man (played by [[Sidney Poitier|Sidney Poitier]]) and a blind white female teenager (played by [[Elizabeth Hartman|Elizabeth Hartman]]), and the problems that plague their relationship when they fall in love in a racially divided America. Made in 1965 against the backdrop of the growing [[civil rights movement|civil rights movement]], the film explores racism from the perspective of "love is blind."
title: A Patch of Blue

abstract: American History X is a 1998 American [[crime|Crime film]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by [[Tony Kaye|Tony Kaye (director)]] and written by [[David McKenna|David McKenna (writer)]]. It stars [[Edward Norton|Edward Norton]] and [[Edward Furlong|Edward Furlong]], and features [[Fairuza Balk|Fairuza Balk]], [[Stacy Keach|Stacy Keach]], [[Elliott Gould|Elliott Gould]], [[Avery Brooks|Avery Brooks]], [[Ethan Suplee|Ethan Suplee]], and [[Beverly D'Angelo|Beverly D'Angelo]]. The film was released in the United States on October 30, 1998, and was distributed by [[New Line Cinema|New Line Cinema]].
title: American History X

abstract: Stand and Deliver is a 1988 American [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] based on the true story of high school math teacher [[Jaime Escalante|Jaime Escalante]]. For portraying Escalante, [[Edward James Olmos|Edward James Olmos]] was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Academy Award for Best Actor]] at the [[61st Academy Awards|61st Academy Awards]]. The film was added to the [[National Film Registry|National Film Registry]] of the [[Library of Congress|Library of Congress]] in 2011.
title: Stand and Deliver

abstract: The story concerns the disintegration of an [[upper-middle class|upper-middle class]] family in [[Lake Forest, Illinois|Lake Forest, Illinois]], following the death of one of their sons in a boating accident. The screenplay by [[Alvin Sargent|Alvin Sargent]] was based upon the 1976 novel [[Ordinary People|Ordinary People (novel)]] by [[Judith Guest|Judith Guest]].
title: Ordinary People

abstract: The Buddy Holly Story is a 1978 [[biographical film|biographical film]] which tells the life story of [[rock music|Rock and rollian]] [[Buddy Holly|Buddy Holly]]. It features an [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]]-winning musical score, adapted by [[Joe Renzetti|Joe Renzetti]] and [[Oscar|Academy Awards]]-nominated lead performance by [[Gary Busey|Gary Busey]].
title: The Buddy Holly Story

abstract: Interiors is a 1978 [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] written and directed by [[Woody Allen|Woody Allen]]. Featured performers are [[Kristin Griffith|Kristin Griffith]], [[Mary Beth Hurt|Mary Beth Hurt]], [[Richard Jordan|Richard Jordan]], [[Diane Keaton|Diane Keaton]], [[E. G. Marshall|E. G. Marshall]], [[Geraldine Page|Geraldine Page]], [[Maureen Stapleton|Maureen Stapleton]] and [[Sam Waterston|Sam Waterston]].
title: Interiors

abstract: Calendar Girls premiered at the [[Locarno Film Festival|Locarno Film Festival]] and was later shown at [[Filmfest Hamburg|Filmfest Hamburg]], the Dinard Festival of British Cinema in [[France|France]], the [[Warsaw Film Festival|Warsaw Film Festival]], the [[Tokyo International Film Festival|Tokyo International Film Festival]] and the UK Film Festival in [[Hong Kong|Hong Kong]]. It garnered generally positive reactions by film critics, who compared with British comedy film [[The Full Monty|The Full Monty]] (1997). At a budget of $10 million it also became a major commercial success, eventually grossing $96,000,000 worldwide following its theatrical release in the United States. In addition, the picture was awarded the [[British Comedy Award|British Comedy Award]] for Best Comedy Film, and spawned [[ALFS Award|ALFS Award]], [[Empire Award|Empire Award]], [[Satellite Award|Satellite Award]] and [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award]] nominations for Mirren and Walters respectively.
title: Calendar Girls

abstract: The Greatest Story Ever Told is a 1965 American [[epic film|epic film]] produced and directed by [[George Stevens|George Stevens]]. It is a retelling of the Biblical account about [[Jesus of Nazareth|Jesus Christ]], from the [[Nativity|Nativity of Jesus]] through to the [[Ascension|Ascension of Jesus]]. Along with the [[ensemble cast|ensemble cast]], it marked [[Claude Rains|Claude Rains]]'s final film role.
title: The Greatest Story Ever Told

abstract: The film was released to positive reviews and was nominated for three [[Academy Awards|Academy Awards]] including [[Best Director|Academy Award for Best Director]] and [[Best Original Screenplay|Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay]], winning [[Best Supporting Actor|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]] for Kline. Cleese and Palin won [[BAFTA Awards|British Academy Film Awards]] for [[Best Actor|BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role]] and [[Best Supporting Actor|BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role]] for their performances. A [[spiritual sequel|spiritual sequel]], [[Fierce Creatures|Fierce Creatures]], was released in 1997. The [[British Film Institute|British Film Institute]] ranked A Fish Called Wanda the [[39th-greatest British film of the 20th century|BFI Top 100 British films]].
title: A Fish Called Wanda

abstract: Disney initially envisioned Toy Story 2 as a [[direct-to-video|direct-to-video]] sequel. The film began production in a building separated from Pixar, on a small scale, as most of the main Pixar staff were busy working on [[A Bug's Life|A Bug's Life]] (1998). When story reels proved promising, Disney upgraded the film to theatrical release, but Pixar was unhappy with the film's quality. Lasseter and the story team redeveloped the entire plot in one weekend. Although most Pixar features take years to develop, the established release date could not be moved and the production schedule for Toy Story 2 was compressed into nine months.
title: Toy Story 2

abstract: The phrase "Pom Poko" in the title refers to the sound of tanuki ([[Japanese raccoon dog|Japanese raccoon dogs]], Nyctereutes procyonoides viverrinus) drumming their own bellies as a form of [[Tanuki-bayashi|Tanuki-bayashi]]. Specifically, the phrase started as a jocular explanation of meditative percussion at [[Shōjō-ji|Shōjō-ji]] taken up in a 1919 poem by [[Ujō Noguchi|Ujō Noguchi]], which became a popular nursery rhyme recorded in 1925.
title: Pom Poko

abstract: Produced by Peters Entertainment and Sonnenfeld-Josephson Worldwide Entertainment, Wild Wild West was released worldwide on June 30, 1999 by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros.]] and was a critical and commercial disappointment, grossing only $222.1 million worldwide against a $170 million budget.
title: Wild Wild West

abstract: Sex, Lies, and Videotape (styled as sex, lies, and videotape) is a 1989 American [[independent|Independent film]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] that brought [[director|Film director]] [[Steven Soderbergh|Steven Soderbergh]] to prominence. The plot tells the story of a troubled man who videotapes women discussing their lives and sexuality, and his impact on the relationships of a troubled married couple and the wife's younger sister.
title: Sex, Lies, and Videotape

abstract: Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb, more commonly known simply as Dr. Strangelove, is a 1964 [[political satire|political satire]] [[black comedy|black comedy]] film that satirizes the [[Cold War|Cold War]] fears of a nuclear conflict between the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union]] and the [[United States|United States]]. The film was directed, produced, and co-written by [[Stanley Kubrick|Stanley Kubrick]], stars [[Peter Sellers|Peter Sellers]], [[George C. Scott|George C. Scott]] and [[Slim Pickens|Slim Pickens]]. Production took place in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]]. The film is loosely based on [[Peter George|Peter George (author)]]'s [[thriller|Thriller (genre)]] novel [[Red Alert|Red Alert (novel)]] (1958).The story concerns an unhinged [[United States Air Force|United States Air Force]] general who orders a [[first strike|first strike]] [[nuclear attack|Nuclear warfare]] on the Soviet Union. It follows the [[President of the United States|President of the United States]], his advisors, the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff|Joint Chiefs of Staff]], and a [[Royal Air Force|Royal Air Force]] (RAF) officer as they try to recall the bombers to prevent a [[nuclear apocalypse|nuclear apocalypse]]. It separately follows the crew of one [[B-52|B-52 Stratofortress]] bomber as they try to deliver their payload.
title: Dr. Strangelove

abstract: Blade Runner is a 1982 [[science fiction film|science fiction film]] directed by [[Ridley Scott|Ridley Scott]], written by [[Hampton Fancher|Hampton Fancher]] and [[David Peoples|David Peoples]], and starring [[Harrison Ford|Harrison Ford]], [[Rutger Hauer|Rutger Hauer]], [[Sean Young|Sean Young]], and [[Edward James Olmos|Edward James Olmos]]. It is a loose [[adaptation|film adaptation]] of [[Philip K. Dick|Philip K. Dick]]'s novel [[Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?|Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?]] (1968). The film is set in a [[dystopia|dystopian]] future [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles]] of 2019, in which [[synthetic humans|android (robot)]] known as [[replicant|replicants]] are [[bio-engineered|bio-engineered]] by the powerful Tyrell Corporation to work on [[off-world colonies|space colonization]]. When a fugitive group of replicants led by [[Roy Batty|Roy Batty]] (Hauer) escapes back to Earth, burnt-out cop [[Rick Deckard|Rick Deckard]] (Ford) reluctantly agrees to hunt them down.
title: Blade Runner

abstract: It is the 16th film in the [[Godzilla franchise|Godzilla (franchise)]] and the first film in the [[Heisei series|Godzilla (franchise)#Heisei period (1984–1995)]], despite having been produced during the [[Shōwa period|Godzilla (franchise)#Shōwa period (1954–1975)]]. The Return of Godzilla serves as both a sequel to the original [[1954 film|Godzilla (1954 film)]] and a [[reboot|Reboot (fiction)]] of the franchise that ignores the events of the Shōwa films, placing itself in line with the darker tone and themes of the original film and returning Godzilla to his destructive, antagonistic roots.
title: The Return of Godzilla

abstract: Galaxy Quest is a 1999 American [[comic science-fiction|comic science fiction]] film directed by [[Dean Parisot|Dean Parisot]] and written by David Howard and [[Robert Gordon|Robert Gordon (screenwriter)]]. A parody of [[science-fiction film|science fiction films]] and [[series|Science fiction on television]], especially [[Star Trek|Star Trek]] and [[its fandom|Trekkie]], the film stars [[Tim Allen|Tim Allen]], [[Sigourney Weaver|Sigourney Weaver]], [[Alan Rickman|Alan Rickman]], [[Tony Shalhoub|Tony Shalhoub]], [[Sam Rockwell|Sam Rockwell]], and [[Daryl Mitchell|Daryl Mitchell (actor)]]. The film depicts the cast of a defunct cult television series called Galaxy Quest who are suddenly visited by actual aliens who believe the series to be an accurate documentary, and become involved in a very real intergalactic conflict.
title: Galaxy Quest

abstract: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre is a 1974 American [[horror film|horror film]] directed by [[Tobe Hooper|Tobe Hooper]] and written and co-produced by Hooper and [[Kim Henkel|Kim Henkel]]. It stars [[Marilyn Burns|Marilyn Burns]], [[Paul A. Partain|Paul A. Partain]], [[Edwin Neal|Edwin Neal]], [[Jim Siedow|Jim Siedow]] and [[Gunnar Hansen|Gunnar Hansen]], who respectively portray [[Sally Hardesty|Sally Hardesty]], Franklin Hardesty, the hitchhiker, the proprietor, and [[Leatherface|Leatherface]]. The film follows a group of friends who fall victim to a family of cannibals while on their way to visit an old homestead. Although it was marketed as a true story to attract a wider audience and as a subtle commentary on the era's political climate, its plot is entirely fictional. However, the character of Leatherface and minor plot details were inspired by the crimes of real-life murderer [[Ed Gein|Ed Gein]].
title: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre

abstract: The Best Years of Our Lives (aka Glory for Me and Home Again) is a 1946 American [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by [[William Wyler|William Wyler]] and starring [[Myrna Loy|Myrna Loy]], [[Fredric March|Fredric March]], [[Dana Andrews|Dana Andrews]], [[Teresa Wright|Teresa Wright]], [[Virginia Mayo|Virginia Mayo]] and [[Harold Russell|Harold Russell]]. The film is about three [[United States servicemen|United States military]] readjusting to civilian life after coming home from [[World War II|World War II]].
