[[Samuel Goldwyn|Samuel Goldwyn]] was inspired to produce a film about veterans after reading an August 7, 1944, article in [[Time|Time (magazine)]] about the difficulties experienced by men returning to civilian life. Goldwyn hired former [[war correspondent|war correspondent]] [[MacKinlay Kantor|MacKinlay Kantor]] to write a screenplay. His work was first published as a novella, Glory for Me, which Kantor wrote in [[blank verse|blank verse]]. [[Robert E. Sherwood|Robert E. Sherwood]] then adapted the novella as a screenplay.The Best Years of Our Lives won seven [[Academy Awards|Academy Awards]] in 1946, including [[Best Picture|Academy Award for Best Picture]], [[Best Director|Academy Award for Best Director]] (William Wyler), [[Best Actor|Academy Award for Best Actor]] (Fredric March), [[Best Supporting Actor|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]] (Harold Russell), [[Best Film Editing|Academy Award for Best Film Editing]] (Daniel Mandell), [[Best Adapted Screenplay|Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]] (Robert E. Sherwood), and [[Best Original Score|Academy Award for Best Original Score]] (Hugo Friedhofer). In addition to its critical success, the film quickly became a great commercial success upon release. It became the highest-grossing film and most attended film in both the United States and UK since the release of [[Gone with the Wind|Gone with the Wind (film)]], selling approximately 55 million tickets in the United States which equaled a gross of $23,650,000. It remains the sixth most-attended film of all time in the UK, with over 20 million tickets sold and ticket sales exceeding US$20.4 million.
title: The Best Years of Our Lives

abstract: From Here to Eternity is a 1953 American [[romantic drama film|romance film]] directed by [[Fred Zinnemann|Fred Zinnemann]], and written by [[Daniel Taradash|Daniel Taradash]], based on the [[novel of the same name|From Here to Eternity (novel)]] by [[James Jones|James Jones (author)]]. The picture deals with the tribulations of three [[U.S. Army|United States Army]] soldiers, played by [[Burt Lancaster|Burt Lancaster]], [[Montgomery Clift|Montgomery Clift]], and [[Frank Sinatra|Frank Sinatra]], stationed on [[Hawaii|Hawaii]] in the months leading up to the [[attack on Pearl Harbor|attack on Pearl Harbor]]. [[Deborah Kerr|Deborah Kerr]] and [[Donna Reed|Donna Reed]] portray the women in their lives, and the supporting cast includes [[Ernest Borgnine|Ernest Borgnine]], [[Philip Ober|Philip Ober]], [[Jack Warden|Jack Warden]], [[Mickey Shaughnessy|Mickey Shaughnessy]], [[Claude Akins|Claude Akins]], and [[George Reeves|George Reeves]].
title: From Here to Eternity

abstract: The Sting is a 1973 American [[caper film|Heist film]] set in September 1936, involving [[a complicated plot|Long con]] by two professional [[grifters|Confidence trick]] ([[Paul Newman|Paul Newman]] and [[Robert Redford|Robert Redford]]) to [[con|Confidence trick]] a mob boss ([[Robert Shaw|Robert Shaw (actor)]]). The film was directed by [[George Roy Hill|George Roy Hill]], who had directed Newman and Redford in the western [[Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid|Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid]]. Created by screenwriter [[David S. Ward|David S. Ward]], the story was inspired by real-life cons perpetrated by brothers Fred and Charley Gondorff and documented by [[David Maurer|David W. Maurer]] in his book The Big Con: The Story of the Confidence Man.
title: The Sting

abstract: The Snake Pit is a 1948 American [[film noir|film noir]] directed by [[Anatole Litvak|Anatole Litvak]] and stars [[Olivia de Havilland|Olivia de Havilland]], [[Mark Stevens|Mark Stevens (actor)]], [[Leo Genn|Leo Genn]], [[Celeste Holm|Celeste Holm]], [[Beulah Bondi|Beulah Bondi]], and [[Lee Patrick|Lee Patrick (actress)]]. Based on [[Mary Jane Ward|Mary Jane Ward]]'s 1946 [[semi-autobiographical novel|Autobiographical novel]] of the same name, the film tells the story of a woman who finds herself in an [[insane asylum|insane asylum]] and cannot remember how she got there.
title: The Snake Pit

abstract: Dangerous Liaisons is a 1988 American [[historical romantic drama film|historical drama film]] directed by [[Stephen Frears|Stephen Frears]] and written by [[Christopher Hampton|Christopher Hampton]] based on his play [[Les liaisons dangereuses|Les Liaisons Dangereuses (Hampton play)]] which was the adaptation of the 18th-century French novel [[of the same name|Les Liaisons dangereuses]] by [[Pierre Choderlos de Laclos|Pierre Choderlos de Laclos]]. It stars [[Glenn Close|Glenn Close]], [[John Malkovich|John Malkovich]], [[Michelle Pfeiffer|Michelle Pfeiffer]], [[Swoosie Kurtz|Swoosie Kurtz]], [[Mildred Natwick|Mildred Natwick]], [[Peter Capaldi|Peter Capaldi]], [[Keanu Reeves|Keanu Reeves]] and [[Uma Thurman|Uma Thurman]].
title: Dangerous Liaisons

abstract: Roman Holiday is a 1953 American [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film directed and produced by [[William Wyler|William Wyler]]. It stars [[Gregory Peck|Gregory Peck]] as a reporter and [[Audrey Hepburn|Audrey Hepburn]] as a royal princess out to see Rome on her own. Hepburn won an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award for Best Actress]] for her performance; the screenplay and costume design also won.
title: Roman Holiday

abstract: Although it was produced with a tight budget, and was relatively unknown until it went on screen (due to virtually no advertising), it broke [[Hong Kong|Hong Kong]]'s box office record and went on to become a blockbuster in [[Asia|Asia]]. It is highly regarded, ranking #2 in the [[Best 100 Chinese Motion Pictures|Hong Kong Film Awards#Best 100 Chinese Motion Pictures]]. Its success also ensured the sequel [[A Better Tomorrow II|A Better Tomorrow II]], also directed by Woo, and [[A Better Tomorrow 3: Love & Death in Saigon|A Better Tomorrow 3]], a [[prequel|prequel]] directed by [[Tsui Hark|Tsui Hark]].
title: A Better Tomorrow

abstract: Icehouse pieces, or Icehouse Pyramids, Treehouse pieces, Treehouse Pyramids and officially Looney Pyramids, are nestable and stackable [[pyramid|pyramid]]-shaped gaming pieces and a game system. The game system was invented by [[Andrew Looney|Andrew Looney]] and John Cooper in 1987, originally for use in the game of [[Icehouse|Icehouse (game)]].
title: Icehouse pieces

abstract: Yahtzee is a [[dice game|dice game]] made by [[Milton Bradley|Milton Bradley Company]] (now owned by [[Hasbro|Hasbro]]), which was first marketed as Yatzie by the National Association Service of Toledo, Ohio, in the early 1940s. Yatzie was included in a game set called LUCK - 15 Grand Dice Games. It was marketed under the name of Yahtzee by game entrepreneur [[Edwin S. Lowe|Edwin S. Lowe]] in 1956. Lowe is also responsible for introducing Bingo to the U.S. market. The game is a development of earlier dice games such as [[Poker Dice|Poker Dice]], [[Yacht|Yacht (dice game)]] and [[Generala|Generala]]. It is also similar to [[Yatzy|Yatzy]], which is popular in Scandinavia.
title: Yahtzee

abstract: The name is a trademark of [[Hasbro, Inc.|Hasbro]] in the United States and Canada; outside these two countries it is a trademark of [[Mattel|Mattel]]. The game is sold in 121 countries and is available in 29 languages; approximately 150 million sets have been sold worldwide and roughly one-third of American and half of British homes have a Scrabble set. There are around 4,000 Scrabble clubs around the world.
title: Scrabble

abstract: Stratego is a [[strategy|Strategy game]] [[board game|board game]] for two players on a board of 10×10 squares. Each player controls 40 pieces representing individual [[officer ranks|Army officer ranks]] in an [[army|army]]. The pieces have [[Napoleonic|Napoleonic]] [[insignia|wikt:insignia]]. The objective of the game is to find and capture the opponent's Flag, or to capture so many enemy pieces that the opponent cannot make any further moves. Stratego has simple enough rules for young children to play, but a depth of strategy that is also appealing to adults. The game is a slightly modified copy of an early 20th century [[French|France]] game named L'Attaque. It has been in production in [[Europe|Europe]] since [[World War II|World War II]] and the [[United States|United States]] since 1961. There are now 2- and 4-handed versions, versions with 10, 30 or 40 pieces per player, and boards with smaller sizes (number of spaces). There are also variant pieces and different rulesets.
title: Stratego

abstract: The Mystara planet also has sub-settings. The older [[Blackmoor|Blackmoor (campaign setting)]] setting was [[retconned|retconned]] to exist in Mystara's distant past. The [[Hollow World|Hollow World]] refers to the inner surface contained within the world of Mystara, similar to the real world legends of the [[Hollow Earth|Hollow Earth]], while some adventures take place on the [[Savage Coast|Savage Coast]], a 2,000 mile long frontier coastline about 2,000 miles to the west of the Known World.
title: Mystara

abstract: Advanced Squad Leader (ASL) is a [[tactical-level|tactical wargames]] [[board wargame|board wargame]], originally marketed by Avalon Hill Games, that simulates actions of squad sized units in [[World War II|World War II]]. It is a detailed game system for two or more players (with solitary play also possible). Components include the ASL Rulebook and various games called modules. ASL modules provide the standard equipment for playing ASL, including [[geomorphic mapboard|geomorphic mapboards]] and [[counters|counter (board wargames)]]. The mapboards are divided into [[hexagons|hex map]] to regulate fire and movement, and depict generic terrain that can represent different historical locations. The counters are cardboard pieces that depict [[squad|squads]] of [[soldier|soldiers]], crews, individual leaders, support weapons, heavy weapons, and vehicles.
title: Advanced Squad Leader

abstract: Risk 2210 A.D. is a 2–5 player [[board game|board game]] by [[Avalon Hill|Avalon Hill]] that is a futuristic variant of the classic board game [[Risk|Risk (game)]]. Risk 2210 A.D. was designed by [[Rob Daviau|Rob Daviau]] and Craig Van Ness and first released in 2001. In 2002, it won the [[Origins Award|Origins Award]] for "Best Science Fiction or Fantasy Board Game of 2001".
title: Risk 2210 A.D.

abstract: Chu shogi (中将棋 chū shōgi or Middle Shogi) is a [[strategy|Abstract strategy game]] [[board game|board game]] native to [[Japan|Japan]]. It is similar to modern [[shogi|shogi]] (sometimes called Japanese chess) in its rules and gameplay. Its name means "mid-sized shogi", from a time when there were three sizes of [[shogi variant|shogi variants]] that were regularly being played. Chu shogi seems to have been developed in the early 14th century as a derivative of [[dai shogi|dai shogi]] ("large shogi"). There are earlier references, but it is not clear that they refer to the game as we now know it.
title: Chu shogi

abstract: Pieces in Squad Leader represent regular squads (rated for firepower, range and morale), weapon and vehicle crews, elite squads (with high firepower and morale but shorter range - used to represent paratroops or combat engineers armed with sub-machine guns), individual leaders, support weapons, and vehicles.
title: Squad Leader

abstract: The Kindred of the Ebony Kingdom, known among themselves as the Laibon, are [[vampires|vampires]] native to [[Africa|Africa]] in the Old [[World of Darkness|World of Darkness]] setting. Though having the same roots as the western Kindred (traditional vampires) and being afflicted with the same curse, the Laibon have existed in relative isolation from the western Kindred for an extended period, and have become distinct in a variety of ways. Additionally, they do not believe themselves descended from Caine (the first vampire), but rather view their existence in relation to various African myths and legends.
title: Kindred of the Ebony Kingdom

abstract: During the game, each player builds out locations around town, while their dudes fight it out for control of the town. Doomtown sets itself apart from other card games in that each card doubles as a [[playing card|playing card]], which impacts both deck building and gameplay. Players resolve certain in-game situations (such as combat) with a hand of [[poker|poker]], accentuating the [[Old West|American frontier]] atmosphere of the game. The game's movement rules are also noteworthy, often being compared to [[chess|chess]].
title: Doomtown

abstract: The game was designed by [[Andrew Looney|Andrew Looney]] of [[Looney Labs|Looney Labs]] in 2000. In 2001, Chrononauts won the [[Origins Award|Origins Award]] for Best Traditional Card Game of 2000 and Parents' Choice Silver Honors 2001 Games.
title: Chrononauts

abstract: Tâb is the [[Egypt|Egyptian]] name of a [[running-fight|Running-fight game]] [[board game|board game]] played in several [[Muslim|Muslim]] (mostly [[Arab|Arab]]) countries, and a family of similar board games played in [[North Africa|North Africa]] (as sîg) and [[Western Asia|Western Asia]], from [[Iran|Iran]] to [[West Africa|West Africa]] and from [[Turkey|Turkey]] to [[Somalia|Somalia]], where a variant called deleb is played. The rules and boards can vary widely across the region though almost all consist of boards with three or four rows. A reference to "at-tâb wa-d-dukk" (likely a similar game) occurs in a poem of 1310 CE.
title: Tâb

abstract: The Universal Fighting System (UFS) is a [[collectible card game|collectible card game]] designed by Jasco Games. Games of UFS represent a fight between two characters in hand-to-hand combat. Characters are drawn from original properties as well as a number of licensed ones, such as [[Mega Man|Mega Man (original series)]], [[Street Fighter|Street Fighter]], [[The King of Fighters XIII|The King of Fighters XIII]] and [[Darkstalkers|Darkstalkers]]. The sets are cross-compatible   – cards from multiple licenses can be included in the same deck, and characters from different universes may face each other in a match.
title: Universal Fighting System

abstract: The Game of the Generals, also called GG or GOG as it is most fondly called, or simply The Generals, is an [[educational|educational]] [[war game|War gaming]] invented in the [[Philippines|Philippines]] by Sofronio H. Pasola, Jr. in [[1970|1970 in games]]. Its Filipino name is "Salpakan." It can be played within twenty to thirty minutes. It is designed for two players, each controlling an army, and a neutral arbiter (sometimes called a referee or an [[adjutant|adjutant]]) to decide the results of "challenges" between opposing playing pieces, that like playing cards, have their identities hidden from the opponent.
title: Game of the Generals

abstract: Poleconomy was invented by Bruce Hatherley, a New Zealander from [[Christchurch|Christchurch]] who was living in [[Sydney|Sydney]] at the time. He first filed a US patent claim for it in January 1981. It was published in 1980, first in an [[Australia|Australian]] edition, then a New Zealand edition. The New Zealand edition was produced by [[Tanner Couch|Tanner Couch]] and Robyn Larsen sold the squares on the board as advertising space to the actual companies represented. The [[New Zealand Stock Exchange|New Zealand Stock Exchange]] was involved with the launch in [[Auckland|Auckland]]. It was also published by World Games.
title: Poleconomy

abstract: The HeroClix game utilizes the "combat dial system" originally created for the [[Mage Knight|Mage Knight]] game. The Combat Dial keeps track of a figure's game statistics via a rotating dial in the base. As the figure suffers damage, the dial is turned required number of "clicks" to reveal new stats and possibly special abilities. HeroClix was designed to appeal to comic book fans and players of [[wargames|wargaming]] and subsequently also became collector items due to the quality of detail in the HeroClix figures. The first game set, Marvel's Infinity Challenge, was released in 2002 and included figures and maps. The original HeroClix figures were all from comic books printed by [[Marvel Comics|Marvel Comics]], but later expanded to include sets from [[DC Comics|DC Comics]] and from various independent comic book publishers such as [[Image Comics|Image Comics]] and [[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Comics]]. Later expansions also added new card-based mechanics such as "Feats" and "Battlefield Conditions", expanding the game beyond the addition of new characters. The Original HeroClix won three awards at the 2002 [[Origins Awards|Origins Awards]] including Best Science Fiction or Fantasy Game Board Game for Marvel HeroClix: Infinity Challenge, "Best Board Game Expansion Or Supplement" and "Best Science Fiction Or Fantasy Miniature" for the [[Sentinel|Sentinel (comics)]] Figure. WizKids had a prize support system for organized tournaments at comic book and hobby shops, as well as regionally and nationally, consisting of special limited edition variant figures given to winners. [[National Entertainment Collectibles Association|National Entertainment Collectibles Association]] (NECA), the current owners of the HeroClix rights, resumed this practice in 2009.
title: HeroClix

abstract: Numenera is set on Earth approximately one billion years in the future. The setting is called "The Ninth World" due to the fact that eight civilizations have risen and fallen prior to the current era.
title: Numenera

abstract: Star Wars: The Card Game is a [[Living Card Game|Fantasy Flight Games#Living Card Games]] (LCG) produced by [[Fantasy Flight Games|Fantasy Flight Games]]. It is a two-player card game set in the [[Star Wars|Star Wars]] universe. It puts one player in command of the light side of the Force (with the affiliations [[Jedi|Jedi]], [[Rebel Alliance|Rebel Alliance]], and Smugglers And Spies making up the light side), and one player in command of the dark side of the Force (made up of [[Sith|Sith]], [[Imperial Navy|Imperial Navy (Star Wars)]], and Scum And Villainy affiliations). The Balance of the Force expansion allows multi-player games. The game is set within the time-frame of the original Star Wars trilogy.Each player has a deck of objective cards representing various missions plus a deck of player cards of units (characters, vehicles, droids and creatures), events, enhancements and fates. Each objective is linked to a set of five player cards. Deck construction consists of choosing which objectives are to go into your objective deck, then adding each of those objective's set of five player cards to your player deck. Game play consists of deploying cards to your tableau, attacking your opponent's objectives, defending your own objectives, and committing cards to the Force Struggle.
title: Star Wars: The Card Game

abstract: Whack & Slaughter is a set of [[fantasy|fantasy]] [[skirmishing game|Man-to-man wargame]] rules allowing you to play with all kinds of [[fantasy|fantasy]] as well as [[pirate|pirate]] themed [[miniatures|Miniature figure (gaming)]]. It is meant to be played with as few as one miniature per player and thus with more players. Most scenarios are meant to be played with up to 8 players forming 2 teams à 4 players (and thus 4 miniatures per team). Additionally to a miniature (referred to as Hero), a player needs a set of 5 dice as well as a "[[Hero Card|Character sheet]]" as a reference for the Hero's abilities.
title: Whack & Slaughter

abstract: Secret Hitler is a hidden identity [[party game|party game]] developed by Goat, Wolf, & Cabbage LLC, manufactured by Breaking Games and distributed by Blackbox. The game was designed by Max Temkin, Mike Boxleiter and Tommy Maranges, with artwork created by Mackenzie Schubert, and first released on August 25, 2016. In Secret Hitler, players assume the roles of [[liberals|Liberalism]] and [[fascists|fascists]] in the [[Reichstag|Reichstag (Weimar Republic)]] of the [[Weimar Republic|Weimar Republic]], with one player becoming [[Adolf Hitler|Adolf Hitler]]. To win the game, both parties are set to competitively enact liberal and fascist policies, respectively, or complete a secondary objective directly involving Hitler.
title: Secret Hitler

abstract: Arkham Horror: The Card Game is produced by [[Fantasy Flight Games|Fantasy Flight Games]]. It is a cooperative game set in the universe of [[Chaosium|Chaosium]]'s [[Call of Cthulhu|Call of Cthulhu (role-playing game)]] [[roleplaying game|roleplaying game]] which is based on the [[Cthulhu Mythos|Cthulhu Mythos]] of [[H.P. Lovecraft|H.P. Lovecraft]] and other [[horror|horror fiction]] writers. The setting of the game is based in the titular (fictional) town of [[Arkham|Arkham]], MA. The game was originally leaked in May 2016, before being officially announced in August of that same year. It made its first limited public release at Arkham Nights 2016 to a sold out crowd.
title: Arkham Horror: The Card Game

abstract: Tic-tac-toe ([[American English|American English]]), noughts and crosses ([[British English|British English]]) or Xs and Os, is a [[paper-and-pencil game|paper-and-pencil game]] for two players, X and O, who take turns marking the spaces in a 3×3 grid. The player who succeeds in placing three of their marks in a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal row wins the game.
title: Tic-tac-toe

abstract: Vs. System (short for Versus System), also written as VS System and abbreviated as VS, is a [[collectible card game|collectible card game]] designed by [[Upper Deck Entertainment|Upper Deck Entertainment]] (UDE). In the game, players build and play a deck of Vs. System cards in an attempt to win a game against their opponent. It was first published in 2004 and is set in the [[superhero|superhero]] genre. The game was discontinued by Upper Deck Entertainment in January 2009.
title: Vs. System

abstract: Axis & Allies Miniatures is a [[miniature wargaming|miniature wargaming]] system including both a rule set and a line of 1/100 scale [[miniature armor|miniature armor]] (15   mm [[figure scale|figure scale]]) collectible miniatures. The game is set in the [[World War II|World War II]] era with units representing individual vehicles and [[artillery|artillery]] or squads of [[infantry|infantry]]. The system was first released in 2005 and is currently produced by [[Avalon Hill|Avalon Hill]], a division of the game company [[Wizards of the Coast|Wizards of the Coast]], which itself is a subsidiary of [[Hasbro|Hasbro]].
title: Axis & Allies Miniatures

abstract: Peter Jeremy William Huggins (3 November 1933 – 12 September 1995), known professionally as Jeremy Brett, was an English actor. He played fictional detective [[Sherlock Holmes|Sherlock Holmes]] in [[four Granada TV series|Sherlock Holmes (1984 TV series)]] from 1984 to 1994 in all 41 episodes. His career spanned from stage, to television and film, to Shakespeare and musical theatre. He is also remembered for playing the besotted Freddie Eynsford-Hill in the 1964 [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros.]] production of [[My Fair Lady|My Fair Lady (film)]].
title: Jeremy Brett

abstract: Edward James Olmos (born February 24, 1947) is an American actor, director, producer, and activist. He is best known for his roles as Lieutenant Martin "Marty" Castillo in [[Miami Vice|Miami Vice]] (1984-1989), [[William Adama|William Adama]] in the re-imagined [[Battlestar Galactica|Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)]] (2004-2009), teacher [[Jaime Escalante|Jaime Escalante]] in [[Stand and Deliver|Stand and Deliver]] (1988), and Detective [[Gaff|Characters in Blade Runner#Gaff]] in [[Blade Runner|Blade Runner]] (1982) and [[Blade Runner 2049|Blade Runner 2049]] (2017). In 2018, he played the father of a gang member in the [[FX|FX (TV channel)]] series, [[Mayans MC|Mayans MC]].
title: Edward James Olmos

abstract: Keisha Castle-Hughes (born 24 March 1990) is a [[New Zealand|New Zealand]] actress who rose to prominence for playing [[Paikea "Pai" Apirana|Paikea]] in the film [[Whale Rider|Whale Rider]]. The film was nominated for many awards, including an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award for Best Actress]] (at the time the youngest person nominated in the Best Actress category) and an award at the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards|Critics' Choice Movie Awards]] for [[Best Young Actor/Actress|Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Young Performer]], which she won in 2004.
title: Keisha Castle-Hughes

abstract: Carly Elisabeth Simon (born June 25, 1945) is an American [[singer-songwriter|singer-songwriter]], musician, and children's author. She first rose to fame in the 1970s with a string of hit records; her 13 [[Top 40|Billboard Hot 100]] U.S. hits include "[[Anticipation|Anticipation (song)]]" (No. 13), "[[You Belong To Me|You Belong to Me (Carly Simon song)]]" (No. 6), "[[Coming Around Again|Coming Around Again (Carly Simon song)]]" (No. 18), and her four [[Gold|Gold album]] certified singles "[[Jesse|Jesse (Carly Simon song)]]" (No. 11), "[[Mockingbird|Mockingbird (Inez & Charlie Foxx song)]]" (No. 5, a duet with [[James Taylor|James Taylor]]), "[[You're So Vain|You're So Vain]]" (No. 1), and "[[Nobody Does It Better|Nobody Does It Better]]" (No. 2) from the 1977 [[James Bond|James Bond]] film, [[The Spy Who Loved Me|The Spy Who Loved Me (film)]].
title: Carly Simon

abstract: Sir Donald Wolfit, [[CBE|Order of the British Empire]] (20 April 1902 – 17 February 1968) was an English [[actor-manager|actor-manager]], known for his touring [[wartime|World War II]] productions of Shakespeare. He was especially renowned for his portrayal of King Lear.
title: Donald Wolfit

abstract: Lana Turner (; born Julia Jean Turner; February 8, 1921June 29, 1995) was an American actress who worked in film, television, theater, and radio. Over the course of her nearly 50-year career, she achieved fame as both a [[pin-up|Pin-up model]] model and a dramatic actress as well as for her highly publicized personal life. In the mid-1940s, she was one of the highest-paid women in the United States, and one of [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]'s (MGM) biggest stars, with her films earning the studio over $50 million during her eighteen-year contract with them. She is frequently cited as a [[popular culture|popular culture]] icon of Hollywood glamour.
title: Lana Turner

abstract: Jean Paul Getty (; December 15, 1892 – June 6, 1976), known widely as J. Paul Getty, was a [[British American|British American]] petrol-industrialist, and the patriarch of the [[Getty family|Getty family]]. He founded the [[Getty Oil Company|Getty Oil]], and in 1957 [[Fortune|Fortune (magazine)]] magazine named him the [[richest living American|Wealthiest Americans (1957)]], while the 1966 [[Guinness Book of Records|Guinness Book of Records]] named him as the world's richest private citizen, worth an estimated $1.2 billion (approximately $ billion in ). At his death, he was worth more than $6 billion (approximately $ billion in ). A book published in 1996 ranked him as the 67th richest American who ever lived, based on his wealth as a percentage of the concurrent [[gross national product|Measures of national income and output]].
title: J. Paul Getty

abstract: Nancy Carroll (born Ann Veronica Lahiff, November 19, 1903 – August 6, 1965) was an American actress.
title: Nancy Carroll

abstract: Bessie Love (born Juanita Horton, September 10, 1898 – April 26, 1986) was an American [[motion picture|motion picture]] actress who achieved prominence mainly in the [[silent films|silent films]] and early [[talkie|talkies]]. With a small frame and delicate features, she played innocent young girls, [[flapper|flappers]], and wholesome leading ladies. Her performance in [[The Broadway Melody|The Broadway Melody]] (1929) earned her a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award for Best Actress]].
title: Bessie Love

abstract: Jack Pickford (born John Charles Smith; August 18, 1896 – January 3, 1933) was a Canadian-born American actor, film director and producer. He was the younger brother of actresses [[Mary|Mary Pickford]] and [[Lottie Pickford|Lottie Pickford]].
title: Jack Pickford

abstract: Judy Holliday (born Judith Tuvim, June 21, 1921 – June 7, 1965) was an American actress, comedian, and singer.She began her career as part of a nightclub act before working in [[Broadway|Broadway theatre]] plays and musicals. Her success in the 1946 stage production of [[Born Yesterday|Born Yesterday (play)]] as Billie Dawn led to her being cast in the [[1950 film version|Born Yesterday (1950 film)]] for which she won an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Academy Award for Best Actress]] and a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]]. She appeared in several films during the 1950s. She was known for her performance on Broadway in the musical [[Bells Are Ringing|Bells Are Ringing (musical)]], winning a [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical|Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical]] and reprising her role in the 1960 film.
title: Judy Holliday

abstract: Jane Wyman (born Sarah Jane Mayfield; January 5, 1917 – September 10, 2007) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and philanthropist whose career spanned seven decades. She was also the first wife of actor [[Ronald Reagan|Ronald Reagan]] (later the 40th [[President of the United States|President of the United States]]). They married in 1940 and divorced in 1949.
title: Jane Wyman

abstract: Darren Aronofsky (born February 12, 1969) is an American [[filmmaker|filmmaker]] and [[screenwriter|screenwriter]], who is noted for his [[surreal|Surrealism]], melodramatic, and often disturbing films.
title: Darren Aronofsky

abstract: Nell Carter (born Nell Ruth Hardy; September 13, 1948 – January 23, 2003) was an American singer and actress.
title: Nell Carter

abstract: Demi Gene Guynes (born November 11, 1962), professionally known as Demi Moore ( ), is an American actress, former songwriter, and model. Moore dropped out of high school at age 16 to pursue an acting career and appeared in the men's [[pornographic magazine|pornographic magazine]] [[Oui|Oui (magazine)]] in 1981. After making her film debut later that year, she appeared on the soap opera [[General Hospital|General Hospital]] and subsequently gained recognition as a member of the [[Brat Pack|Brat Pack (actors)]] with roles in [[Blame It on Rio|Blame It on Rio]] (1984), [[St. Elmo's Fire|St. Elmo's Fire (film)]] (1985), and [[About Last Night...|About Last Night (1986 film)]] (1986).
title: Demi Moore

abstract: Harry James was born in [[Albany, Georgia|Albany, Georgia]], the son of Everett Robert James, a bandleader in a traveling [[circus|circus]], the [[Mighty Haag Circus|Mighty Haag Circus]], and Myrtle Maybelle (Stewart), an acrobat and horseback rider. He started performing with the circus at an early age, first as a contortionist at age four, then playing the snare drum in the band from about the age of six. It was at this age that James was almost trampled by the circus trick horses after he wandered onto the circus track as they were performing their stunts, but fortunately he was protected by his mother's pet horse, who stood over him until the other horses rushed by.James started taking trumpet lessons from his father at age eight, and by age twelve he was leading the second band in the Christy Brothers Circus, for which his family was then working. James's father placed him on a strict daily practice schedule. At each session he was given several pages to learn from the [[Arban's book|Arban method]] and was not allowed to pursue any other pastime until he had learned them. While still a student at Dick Dowling Junior High School, he participated as a regular member of Beaumont High School's Royal Purple Band, and in May 1931 he took first place as trumpet soloist at the Texas Band Teacher's Association's Annual Eastern Division contest held in [[Temple, Texas|Temple, Texas]].
title: Harry James

abstract: Natalie Jane Imbruglia ( ; ; born 4 February 1975) is an [[Australian|Australian]] singer-songwriter, model and actress, naturalised in the UK. In the early 1990s, she played [[Beth Brennan|Beth Brennan]] in the Australian soap opera [[Neighbours|Neighbours]]. Three years after leaving the programme, she began a singing career with her successful hit cover of [[Ednaswap|Ednaswap]]'s song "[[Torn|Torn (Ednaswap song)#Natalie Imbruglia version]]".
title: Natalie Imbruglia

abstract: Oasis' debut album, [[Definitely Maybe|Definitely Maybe]] (1994), marked the beginning of the band's rise to fame as part of the [[Britpop|Britpop]] movement. Oasis' second album, [[(What's the Story) Morning Glory?|(What's the Story) Morning Glory?]] (1995), reached the top of the album charts in many countries and their third studio album, [[Be Here Now|Be Here Now (album)]] (1997), became the fastest-selling album in UK chart history. Britpop eventually declined in popularity and Oasis' next two albums failed to revive it. However, the band's final two albums, [[Don't Believe the Truth|Don't Believe the Truth]] (2005) and [[Dig Out Your Soul|Dig Out Your Soul]] (2008), were hailed as its best efforts in over a decade and found renewed success. In 2009, following an altercation with Liam, Noel Gallagher announced his departure from Oasis and confirmed he would embark on a solo career. Gallagher would go on to form [[Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds|Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds]], with whom he has released three studio albums.
title: Noel Gallagher

abstract: Ben Vereen (born October 10, 1946) is an American [[actor|actor]], [[dancer|dancer]], and [[singer|singer]] who has appeared in numerous [[Broadway theatre|Broadway theatre]] shows. Vereen graduated from Manhattan's [[High School of Performing Arts|High School of Performing Arts]].
title: Ben Vereen

abstract: Nicholas Brendon was born Nicholas Brendon Schultz on April 12, 1971, in Los Angeles, three minutes after his identical twin brother, Kelly Donovan.
title: Nicholas Brendon

abstract: Emma Caulfield Ford (born Emma M. Chukker; April 8, 1973) is an American actress best known for her role as [[Anya Jenkins|Anya Jenkins]] on the television series [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]] (1998–2003), as well as Susan Keats, a [[love interest|Romantic interest]] of [[Brandon Walsh|Brandon Walsh]]'s on the television series [[Beverly Hills, 90210|Beverly Hills, 90210]]. Her film roles include [[Darkness Falls|Darkness Falls (2003 film)]] (2003) and [[TiMER|Timer (film)]] (2009).
title: Emma Caulfield

abstract: Samantha Eggar (born 5 March 1939) is an English-American film, stage, television, and voice actress. After beginning her career in Shakespearean theatre, she rose to fame for her performance in [[William Wyler|William Wyler]]'s thriller [[The Collector|The Collector (1965 film)]] (1965), which earned her a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama]] and an [[Academy Award|Academy Award for Best Actress]] nomination for Best Actress.
title: Samantha Eggar

abstract: Marie Josephine Hull (née Sherwood; January 3, 1877 – March 12, 1957) was an American stage and film actress who also was a director of plays. She had a successful 50-year career on stage while taking some of her better known roles to film. She won an [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for the movie [[Harvey|Harvey (film)]] (1950), a role she originally played on the [[Broadway|Broadway (theatre)]] stage. She was sometimes credited as Josephine Sherwood.
title: Josephine Hull

abstract: Kimberly Denise Jones (born July 11, 1974 or 1975), known professionally by her [[stage name|stage name]] Lil' Kim, is an American [[rapper|Rapping]], songwriter, record producer, model, and actress. She was born and raised in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn]], [[New York|New York (state)]], living much of her adolescent life on the streets after being expelled from home. In her teens, Jones would [[freestyle rap|freestyle rap]], heavily influenced by fellow female hip-hop artists like [[MC Lyte|MC Lyte]] and [[The Lady of Rage|The Lady of Rage]]. In 1994, she was discovered by fellow rapper [[The Notorious B.I.G.|The Notorious B.I.G.]], who invited her to join his rap group [[Junior M.A.F.I.A.|Junior M.A.F.I.A.]]; their debut album as a group, [[Conspiracy|Conspiracy (Junior M.A.F.I.A. album)]], generated two top 20 singles in the United States and was certified [[gold|Gold certification]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA)|Recording Industry Association of America]].
title: Lil' Kim

abstract: Born Shawntae Harris on April 14, 1974, in [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet, Illinois]], Brat was raised on the [[West Side|West Side, Chicago]] of [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago, Illinois]]. Born to David Ray McCoy (1935–1988), a Chicago [[businessman|businessman]] and Nadine Brewer, a Chicago city bus driver, Her parents never married. Brat was subsequently raised in two different households. Da Brat lived part of the time with her mother and grandmother and attended a strict [[Apostolic|Apostolic Church (denomination)]] church four times a week, where she sang in the choir. Da Brat attended [[Kenwood Academy|Kenwood Academy]] during her sophomore and junior year, where she ran track and played basketball. She graduated from the Academy of Scholastic Achievement, a continuation [[charter school|charter school]] that caters to [[at-risk students|at-risk students]] in 1992.
title: Da Brat

abstract: Wah Yan College, Hong Kong (WYHK; [[demonym|demonym]]: Wahyanite, pl.: Wahyanites) along with her brother school Wah Yan College Kowloon is a grant-in-aid secondary school in Hong Kong. Founded on 16 December 1919 by Tsui Yan Sau Peter (1889–1980), it is now a Roman Catholic secondary school for boys run by the Chinese Province of the [[Society of Jesus|Society of Jesus]].
title: Wah Yan College, Hong Kong

abstract: The Diocesan Boys' School (DBS) () is a boys' school in Hong Kong, located at 131 [[Argyle Street|Argyle Street, Hong Kong]], [[Mong Kok|Mong Kok]], [[Kowloon|Kowloon]]. Founded in 1869, it is one of the oldest secondary schools in the city. The school's mission is "to provide a liberal education based on Christian principles". Having run as a grant-aided school since it was founded, the school commenced operation in the [[Direct Subsidy Scheme|Direct Subsidy Scheme]] in September 2003. It uses English as the medium of instruction.
title: Diocesan Boys' School

abstract: Jarvis Collegiate Institute is located on [[Jarvis Street|Jarvis Street]]. Founded in 1807, it is the second oldest high school in Ontario after the [[Kingston Collegiate and Vocational Institute|Kingston Collegiate and Vocational Institute]] (c. 1792), and the oldest high school in Toronto.
title: Jarvis Collegiate Institute

abstract: Pine View School for the Gifted is a public, [[college-preparatory|college-preparatory]], coeducational school located in [[Osprey|Osprey, Florida]], [[Florida|Florida]]. The school is the only full-time program in Florida for intellectually gifted students in the elementary through high school level. The mission of Pine View School is to provide a qualitatively different learning environment that nurtures a passion for intellectual curiosity; encourages risk taking, and independence; and is committed to a tradition of academic excellence and social responsibility. There are currently around 2,210 students at Pine View. Pine View serves students in 2nd through 12th [[grades|Educational stages]].
title: Pine View School

abstract: Bellevue West High School is a [[public|public education]] [[secondary school|secondary education]] located in [[Bellevue, Nebraska|Bellevue, Nebraska]], United States. It had a 2013 enrollment of 1,584 students. The [[principal|school principal]] is Kevin Rohlfs. The school's athletic teams are the Thunderbirds, and their [[school colors|school colors]] are purple, gold and white. The school's cross-town rival is [[Bellevue East|Bellevue East High School]]. Bellevue West is [[accredited|school accreditation]] by the North Central Association Commission on Accreditation and School Improvement. The school also serves as an off-campus location for the [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha, Nebraska]], [[Metropolitan Community College|Metropolitan Community College (Omaha)]].
title: Bellevue West High School

abstract: Canyon del Oro High School (CDO) is a comprehensive [[public high school|public high school]] in [[Oro Valley, Arizona|Oro Valley, Arizona]], located north of [[Tucson|Tucson, Arizona]] at the base of [[Pusch Ridge|Pusch Ridge]]. Established as a high school in 1964, CDO is one of three high schools of [[Amphitheater Public Schools|Amphitheater Public Schools]] and serves about 1,600 students in grades 9–12. The school name originates from the remote Canyon del Oro (Spanish for Canyon of Gold) in the nearby [[Santa Catalina Mountains|Santa Catalina Mountains]] north of Tucson. The school mascot is the [[Dorado|Legend of El Dorado]] (from the [[Legend of El Dorado|Legend of El Dorado]]), a mythical [[Latin American|Latin American]] warrior, and the school colors are forest green and gold. The Dorado mascot was originally designed by former art teacher Diane Redhair in the mid-1960s.
title: Canyon del Oro High School

abstract: The International School of Phnom Penh (ISPP) is an [[international school|international school]] in [[Phnom Penh|Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia|Cambodia]]. It is a private, non-profit, English language, coeducational day school that offers an educational program from preschool (2.5 years old) through grade 12. The school was founded in 1989. At the beginning of the 2013-2014 school year, enrollment is 693 students, representing 50 countries.
title: International School of Phnom Penh

abstract: Cashmere High School () is a state coeducational secondary school, located in southern [[Christchurch|Christchurch]], New Zealand. It was opened in 1956 in response to population growth in southern Christchurch during the 1950s.
title: Cashmere High School

abstract: Wichita Heights High School, known locally as Heights, is a [[coeducation|coeducational]] [[secondary school|secondary school]] located in [[Wichita, Kansas|Wichita, Kansas]], [[USA|United States]], serving students in grades 9-12. The school is part of the [[USD 259|List of unified school districts in Kansas]] public school system. The [[school principal|school principal]] is Sherman Padgett, who replaced Bruce Deterding after Deterding moved to leadership at North in 2018. The school colors are red and black.
title: Wichita Heights High School

abstract: The roots of Midland Public Schools go back to the 1872 Union High School, which educated local students until a boiler explosion destroyed the building in 1907. A new school was constructed the following year using a large donation from the local [[Dow Chemical Company|Dow Chemical Company]]. The institution was renamed [[Midland High School|Midland High School (Midland, Michigan)]] (MHS), and their nickname was “Chemics”. By the mid-1930s, the student population had grown and the second, larger MHS was built in 1937. The 1908 (first) MHS was used as an elementary school, then as the intermediate school until [[Northeast Intermediate|Northeast Middle School (Midland, MI)]] was opened in 1950. Student populations climbed higher and a third MHS was completed in late 1955, larger than ever. For the 1956-57 school year, the high school moved to the new building and the 1937 (second) MHS became [[Central Intermediate|Central Middle School (Midland, Michigan)]], the second middle school in Midland. The 1908 (first) MHS was torn down in 1957. For the 1963-64 school year, [[Jefferson Intermediate|Jefferson Middle School (Midland, MI)]] was opened to handle children from the [[Post-World War II baby boom|Post-World War II baby boom]]. Midland High School was overcrowded again, but the decision was made to build a second high school in Midland, less than ten years after the current MHS was completed. [[Herbert Henry Dow High School|Herbert Henry Dow High School]] opened to sophomores in 1968, and added one grade each year until the first class graduated in 1971. A freshman class was added to high schools in 1997 and intermediate schools changed from grades 7-8-9 to 6-7-8; school names were changed from Intermediate to Middle School. Elementary schools gained classrooms when they lost grade 6.
title: Midland Public Schools

abstract: Harbord Collegiate Institute (H.C.I. or Harbord) is a public [[secondary school|secondary school]] located in downtown [[Toronto, Ontario|Toronto]], Canada. The school is located in the [[Palmerston-Little Italy|Palmerston-Little Italy]]-[[Annex|The Annex]] neighbourhood, situated on the north side of Harbord Street, between Euclid Avenue and Manning Street. From the 1920s to the 1950s, about 90% of the student body was Jewish, whole today the student body largely consists of students of [[East Asian people|East Asian]] and [[Portuguese|Portuguese people]] descent.
title: Harbord Collegiate Institute

abstract: Blue Valley North High School is a fully accredited public high school located in [[Overland Park, Kansas|Overland Park, Kansas]], United States, serving students in grades 9-12. The school is one of the five currently-operated [[high schools|high schools]] in the [[Blue Valley School District|Blue Valley School District]]. The school colors are navy blue and silver. The current enrollment is approximately 1,550 students. The principal is Tyson Ostroski.
title: Blue Valley North High School

abstract: The Ruth Asawa San Francisco School of the Arts is the only San Francisco public high school with an audition process for admission. Prospective students can choose to apply to one of the various disciplines: Architecture and Design, Creative Writing and Spoken Word, Dance, Instrumental Music (Band, Guitar, Orchestra), Media and Film, Musical Theatre, Piano, Technical Theater, Theatre, Visual, Vocal (both Classical Voice and Jazz Vocal) and World Music and Dance.
title: Ruth Asawa San Francisco School of the Arts

abstract: Guelph's largest high school was originally named John F. Ross, in honour of John Francis Ross, a highly respected Guelph band director. The school opened its doors in 2018 60 students with 25 teachers and Santa Claus was the first principal, under the new name John F. Ross Collegiate Vocational Institute. It celebrated its 50th anniversary with a reunion in May 2006.
title: John F. Ross Collegiate Vocational Institute

abstract: Chong Hwa Independent High School, Kuala Lumpur () is one of [[Malaysia|Malaysia]]'s oldest [[high school|high schools]]. Established in 1919 in [[Setapak|Setapak]], [[Kuala Lumpur|Kuala Lumpur]], the school was a [[primary school|primary school]]. It became a high school when the school board purchased a piece of land of 24,000 square metres along [[Jalan Ipoh|Jalan Ipoh]] and decided to move the school there. It has remained there ever since.
title: Chong Hwa Independent High School, Kuala Lumpur

abstract: Trinity College School (TCS) is a coeducational, independent boarding/day school located in [[Port Hope|Port Hope, Ontario]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], [[Canada|Canada]]. TCS was founded on May 1, 1865, more than 2 years prior to [[Canadian Confederation|Canadian Confederation]]. It includes a Senior School for grades 9 to 12 and a Junior School for grades 5 to 8.Among its notable alumni (Old Boys) are The Honourable Mr. Justice [[Ian Binnie|Ian Binnie]], [[William Bridges|William Bridges (general)]], [[Edgar Bronfman, Sr.|Edgar Bronfman, Sr.]], [[Ian Brown|Ian Brown (journalist)]], [[Lew Cirne|Lew Cirne]], [[Reginald Fessenden|Reginald Fessenden]], [[Roy Heenan|Roy Heenan]], [[Peter Jennings|Peter Jennings]], [[Archibald Lampman|Archibald Lampman]], [[Archibald Cameron Macdonell|Archibald Cameron Macdonell]], [[Yann Martel|Yann Martel]], [[Mark McKinney|Mark McKinney]], [[David Macfarlane|David Macfarlane]], [[Sir William Osler|Sir William Osler]], [[Peter Raymont|Peter Raymont]], [[Godfrey D. Rhodes|Godfrey D. Rhodes]], [[Casimir Cartwright van Straubenzee|Casimir Cartwright van Straubenzee]] and [[Charles Taylor|Charles Taylor (philosopher)]]. [[Conrad Black|Conrad Black]] lasted less than a year when he attended Trinity College School before being expelled for insubordinate behaviour.
title: Trinity College School

abstract: Maris Stella College is a Catholic College in [[Negombo|Negombo]], [[Sri Lanka|Sri Lanka]], and was founded by the [[Marist Brothers|Marist Brothers]] in 1922.
title: Maris Stella College

abstract: The first Dallastown High School class graduated in 1898. The first constructed building to house the newly created Dallastown High School, a combination of local schoolhouses, was on Charles St. in Dallastown, now Dallastown Elementary. This building became too small, and effective July 1, 1958; the school districts of Loganville, Springfield and York Township became the York Imperial Union School District. Accordingly, the Dallastown Area School System, which operated all of the schools in the area, grades 1 through 12, was composed of three member districts: Dallastown Borough, Yoe Borough and York Imperial Union. Realizing an immediate need for a building for secondary school purposes, a site was selected and construction of a building began. On September 1, 1958, the doors of the new Dallastown Area High School opened. The Dallastown Area High School was first constructed in 1958 and underwent a major renovation and remodel in 2001.
title: Dallastown Area High School

abstract: Nantyr Shores Secondary School is a public [[secondary school|secondary school]] (grades 9-12) located in the community of [[Alcona|Alcona, Town of Innisfil, Ontario]] in the Town of [[Innisfil, Ontario|Innisfil, Ontario]], [[Canada|Canada]]. It is part of the [[Simcoe County District School Board|Simcoe County District School Board]] and has an enrollment of about 1000 students (2016–2017). The principal of the school is Liselle Prickett and vice principals are Allison Reid & Jeremy Oxley.
title: Nantyr Shores Secondary School

abstract: St. Clare's Girls' School ([[Chinese:|Chinese language]] 聖嘉勒女書院; abbr.: SCGS) is a [[Catholic|Catholic]] [[English|English language]] girls' school located on Mount Davis Road, [[Hong Kong|Hong Kong]]. It was founded in 1927 by the Missionary Sisters of Our Lady of the Angels from [[Lennoxville|Lennoxville]], [[Quebec|Quebec]], [[Canada|Canada]].
title: St. Clare's Girls' School

abstract: Wyandotte High School is a fully accredited public high school located in [[Kansas City|Kansas City, Kansas]], [[Kansas|Kansas]], [[United States|United States]], serving students in grades 9–12. The building itself is a historic and notable public building, which was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places|National Register of Historic Places]] in 1986. The school principal is Mary Stewart. The mascot is the Bulldog and the school colors are red and white. The athletic programs have won many state championships including an undefeated national championship in boys' basketball in 1923.
title: Wyandotte High School

abstract: Littleton Public Schools (aka Arapahoe County School District No. 6 or LPS) is a [[school district|school district]] in [[Littleton|Littleton, Colorado]], [[Colorado|Colorado]] which serves several communities within the southern Denver metropolitan area. It is governed by a five-member Board of Education, and administered by a superintendent and four executives. Its headquarters, the Education Services Center, is located in Downtown Littleton. It is the fifteenth largest school district in Colorado. LPS operates 13 elementary schools, four middle schools, three high schools, several alternative programs, a preschool, and two charter schools.
title: Littleton Public Schools

abstract: Shawnee Mission North High School is a [[public|Public high school]] [[secondary school|secondary school]] in [[Overland Park|Overland Park, Kansas]], [[Kansas|Kansas]], United States, for grades [[9|Ninth grade]]–[[12|Twelfth grade]]. It is one of five schools operated by [[Unified School District|Unified school district]] 512.
title: Shawnee Mission North High School

abstract: Burnsville High School originally opened in 1957 as a [[K|kindergarten]]-[[12|12th grade]] school with an initial enrollment of about 400 students. In 1966, upon completion of the newly constructed school, students in grades seven through nine started attending Metcalf Junior High. Today, students attending Burnsville's Metcalf, Eagle Ridge and Nicollet Middle Schools will attend Burnsville Senior High School for grades 9-12.
title: Burnsville High School

abstract: Cheung Chuk Shan College is an aided, whole-day co-educational grammar secondary school founded in Hong Kong in 1969 by a group of philanthropists of the Five Districts Business Welfare Association. The School is named after Mr. Cheung Chuk Shan (1882 – 1936), a famous merchant in South China in the early 20th century. The school motto, “Competent, Conscientious, Studious & Creative”, bears the initials of the school name “CCSC”. It is engraved in the school badge and expresses the four indispensable qualities expected to be cultivated in its students' pursuit towards whole-person development. [1]
title: Cheung Chuk Shan College

abstract: "The Battle of Evermore" is a [[folk|Folk music]] duet sung by [[Robert Plant|Robert Plant]] and [[Sandy Denny|Sandy Denny]], featured on [[Led Zeppelin|Led Zeppelin]]'s untitled 1971 album, commonly known as [[Led Zeppelin IV|Led Zeppelin IV]]. The song's instrumentation features [[acoustic guitar|acoustic guitar]] and [[mandolin|mandolin]] playing.
title: The Battle of Evermore

abstract: Written in 1992, "Serve the Servants" was the only In Utero song that had never been recorded as a demo by the full band prior to being recorded for the album. As Nirvana's bassist [[Krist Novoselic|Krist Novoselic]] remembers, it was brought to the studio "pretty much done" by Cobain. The album was recorded in February 1993 by [[Steve Albini|Steve Albini]] at [[Pachyderm Studio|Pachyderm Studio]] in [[Cannon Falls, Minnesota|Cannon Falls, Minnesota]].
title: Serve the Servants

abstract: "Scentless Apprentice" is a song by American [[grunge|grunge]] band [[Nirvana|Nirvana (band)]], written by vocalist and guitarist [[Kurt Cobain|Kurt Cobain]], bassist [[Krist Novoselic|Krist Novoselic]], and drummer [[Dave Grohl|Dave Grohl]]. It is the second track on their third and final studio album [[In Utero|In Utero (album)]], released in September 1993.
title: Scentless Apprentice

abstract: "Hero of War" is a 2008 song by [[Rise Against|Rise Against]] from the album [[Appeal to Reason|Appeal to Reason]]. The song was mistaken to be the album's third single, after a music video of the song was released on the band's [[Myspace|Myspace]] on May 20, 2009. However, It was later revealed it was just a promotional video and "[[Savior|Savior (Rise Against song)]]" is in fact, the third single.
title: Hero of War

abstract: "Show Me Love (Not a Dream)" is a song by Japanese [[singer-songwriter|singer-songwriter]] [[Hikaru Utada|Hikaru Utada]]. Used as the theme song for the film [[Tomorrow's Joe|Tomorrow's Joe]] (2011), it was released as a digital download preceding Utada's second Japanese compilation album, [[Utada Hikaru Single Collection Vol. 2|Utada Hikaru Single Collection Vol. 2]], on November 17, 2010.
title: Show Me Love (Not a Dream)

abstract: "Off & On" is a [[pop|Pop music]] song released by British recording artist [[Sophie Ellis-Bextor|Sophie Ellis-Bextor]] as the fifth overall single from her fourth studio album, [[Make a Scene|Make a Scene]]. It was released on 11 April 2011, exclusively in the [[Russian Federation|Russian Federation]] as a digital download, a week before the release of the album there. Ellis-Bextor appeared on various talk shows in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] to promote the song, including [[The Rob Brydon Show|The Rob Brydon Show]], despite it not being released as a single there.
title: Off & On

abstract: "Big Fat Bass" is a song recorded by American singer [[Britney Spears|Britney Spears]] for her seventh studio album [[Femme Fatale|Femme Fatale (Britney Spears album)]] (2011). The [[house|house music]] song was written and produced by [[will.i.am|will.i.am]] as a celebration to the [[bass|Bass (instrument)]] and its influence on club music. The song contains a [[double entendre|double entendre]] gender metaphor sung by Spears. "Big Fat Bass" received mixed reviews from contemporary music critics, who deemed it as an instant radio and club hit, and also considered it the most old-school work on the album. However, a few reviews considered it as an unfortunate collaboration with will.i.am, and dismissed Spears' heavily processed vocals.
title: Big Fat Bass

abstract: "Ik Junoon (Paint It Red)" ([[Hindi|Hindi language]]: इक जूनून; ) is a song by composer trio [[Shankar Ehsaan Loy|Shankar Ehsaan Loy]] for the film [[Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara|Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara]]. The song was performed by [[Clinton Cerejo|Clinton Cerejo]], [[Vishal Dadlani|Vishal Dadlani]] and [[Alyssa Mendonsa|Alyssa Mendonsa]] while the lyrics was penned by [[Javed Akhtar|Javed Akhtar]].
title: Ik Junoon (Paint It Red)

abstract: "V slepých uličkách" () is a duet by [[Miro Žbirka|Miro Žbirka]] and [[Marika Gombitová|Marika Gombitová]] released on [[OPUS|OPUS Records]] in 1980.
title: V slepých uličkách

abstract: Following the release of her first Spanish-language album [[Como Ama una Mujer|Como Ama una Mujer]] (2007), Lopez began working on her sixth studio album, which she confirmed would return her to the [[pop|Pop music]], [[R&B|Contemporary R&B]] and [[hip-hop|hip-hop]] music of her previous English studio album [[Rebirth|Rebirth (Jennifer Lopez album)]] (2005); promising fans "[[dance-able music|dance music]]". The album was later announced to be Brave. Of the concept behind the album, Lopez stated: "When I was making the music and listening to it, I realized I am looking at my own experiences, and to me that is a very brave thing to do, to put that out there. This is what I've been about, not just in love and relationships, but also in life. Not being afraid, just going for it". "Mile in These Shoes", one of the songs on the album, was used for promotion for the popular American [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] television series [[Desperate Housewives|Desperate Housewives]].
title: Mile in These Shoes

abstract: "I Wanna Go Crazy" is a song recorded by [[French|French people]] [[disc jockey|disc jockey]], [[David Guetta|David Guetta]]. It features guest vocals by American rapper, [[will.i.am|will.i.am]] from [[The Black Eyed Peas|The Black Eyed Peas]] and was released digitally on 24 August 2009 worldwide. It also appeared on Guetta's fourth studio album, [[One Love|One Love (David Guetta album)]].
title: I Wanna Go Crazy

abstract: "Let Us Move On" is a song by English singer [[Dido|Dido (singer)]]. It features the vocals from American rapper [[Kendrick Lamar|Kendrick Lamar]]. The song was released in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] on 17 December 2012 as a promotional single from her fourth studio album [[Girl Who Got Away|Girl Who Got Away]] (2013).
title: Let Us Move On

abstract: "Roc Me Out" was written by [[Ester Dean|Ester Dean]], [[Robert Swire|Robert Swire]], [[Gareth McGrillen|Pendulum (drum and bass band)]], [[Mikkel S. Eriksen|Mikkel S. Eriksen]] and [[Tor Erik Hermansen|Tor Erik Hermansen]]. The song was produced by [[StarGate|Stargate (production team)]] (Eriksen and Hermansen) and [[Knife Party|Knife Party]] (Swire and McGrillen). Dean and Stargate have collaborated on Rihanna's previous songs including "[[Rude Boy|Rude Boy (Rihanna song)]]" ([[Rated R|Rated R (Rihanna album)]], 2009) and "[[S&M|S&M (song)]]" ([[Loud|Loud (Rihanna album)]], 2010). Eriksen and Miles Walker recorded "Roc Me Out" at Roc the Mic Studios in New York City, [[Westlake Recording Studios|Westlake Recording Studios]] in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles]] and The Hide Out Studios in [[London|London]]. It was mixed by [[Phil Tan|Phil Tan]], while Daniella Rivera served as a mixing assistant. The song's vocal production was completed by [[Kuk Harrell|Kuk Harrell]], with the vocal recording done by Marcos Tovar and Harrell himself. The instrumentation of the song was made by Eriksen and Hermansen. Tim Blacksmith and Danny D. were signed as executive producers of "Roc Me Out".
title: Roc Me Out

abstract: "Vida 23" is a song from American rapper [[Pitbull|Pitbull (rapper)]]'s fifth studio album, [[Armando|Armando (album)]]. The song was written by [[Clinton Sparks|Clinton Sparks]], [[William Grigahcine|DJ Snake]], [[Armando Pérez|Pitbull (rapper)]], and it was produced by Clinton Sparks and DJ Snake. The song was solely created for Pitbull's campaign with Dr. Pepper.
title: Vida 23

abstract: "Shady Love" is a song by [[American|United States]] [[pop|Pop music]] band [[Scissor Sisters|Scissor Sisters]] which features front-man [[Jake Shears|Jake Shears]]' pseudonym Krystal Pepsy and uncredited vocals from [[Harlem|Harlem]] rapper [[Azealia Banks|Azealia Banks]]. The song was set for release in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] on February 12, 2012 as the [[lead single|lead single]] from the band's fourth [[studio album|studio album]] (2012), but the release was cancelled for unconfirmed reasons. The track was written by frontman [[Jake Shears|Jake Shears]], Azealia Banks and was produced by [[Alex Ridha|Boys Noize]] (who also co-wrote the song). "Shady Love" received its first play on January 2 by [[BBC Radio 1|BBC Radio 1]] DJ [[Annie Mac|Annie Mac]] and was met with positive reviews, including [[NME|NME]] who described it as "the first big hit of 2012".
title: Shady Love

abstract: "Invading My Mind" is a song recorded by American entertainer [[Jennifer Lopez|Jennifer Lopez]] for her seventh studio album [[Love?|Love?]] (2011). It was written by [[RedOne|RedOne]], [[AJ Junior|AJ Junior]], BeatGeek, Teddy Sky, [[Bilal "The Chef"|Bilal Hajji]], Jimmy Joker and produced by RedOne, Lopez, [[Lady Gaga|Lady Gaga]], BeatGeek, Jimmy Joker and [[Kuk Harrell|Kuk Harrell]]. "Invading My Mind" is an uptempo song that speaks of being overcome with a feeling that's "attacking, invading my mind".
title: Invading My Mind

abstract: "Dressin' Up" is a song by American singer [[Katy Perry|Katy Perry]] from [[Teenage Dream: The Complete Confection|Teenage Dream: The Complete Confection]] (2012). It was [[written|Songwriting]] by Perry, [[Christopher "Tricky" Stewart|Christopher Stewart (music producer)]], Monte Neuble, and [[Matt Thiessen|Matt Thiessen]], and [[produced|Production (music)]] by Stewart and [[Kuk Harrell|Kuk Harrell]]. Musically, "Dressin' Up" incorporates the styles of [[electro|Electro (music)]] and [[dance-rock|dance-rock]], along with a prominent [[electronic dance|Electronic dance music]] production. Lyrically, the song speaks of dressing up in different outfits for a lover, and contains multiple innuendos. "Dressin' Up" garnered mixed reviews from critics, some of whom complimented its "fun" sound, while others denounced it as being too similar to Perry's other works. Upon the release of Teenage Dream: The Complete Confection, the song charted on the [[UK Singles Chart|UK Singles Chart]] at number 109.
title: Dressin' Up

abstract: "Screw You" is a song recorded by English recording artist [[Cheryl Cole|Cheryl Cole]] and British [[hip hop|hip hop music]] artist [[Wretch 32|Wretch 32]] for Cole's third studio album [[A Million Lights|A Million Lights]] (2012). "Screw You" was produced by Hy-Grade and written by Megan Nicolle Thomaston, Kingsley Brown, [[Daniel Traynor|Grades (producer)]] and Wretch 32 (Jermaine Scott).
title: Screw You

abstract: In an interview with Booska-P, Orelsan explained that "les backs" (the backs) in the title refer to the words that background singers or rappers repeat at the end of a line in a song. He also explained that the title "Fais les backs" is a reflection of his and his friends' way of life, stating that "we have the same life."
title: Fais les backs

abstract: The song is also used in the 2004 film "Hum, hum från Humlegårn" [[Håkan Bråkan & Josef|Håkan Bråkan & Josef]] (2004).
title: Hum, hum från Humlegårn

abstract: "Champagne Problems" is a song recorded by American singer [[Nick Jonas|Nick Jonas]] from his third studio album, [[Last Year Was Complicated|Last Year Was Complicated]]. It was released on April 8, 2016, by Island, Safehouse and Republic Records as the album's first promotional single. The song was written by [[Nick Jonas|Nick Jonas]], [[Jason Evigan|Jason Evigan]], [[Sean Douglas|Sean Douglas (songwriter)]], [[Jonathan Tucker|Jonathan Tucker]], and [[PJ Bianco|PJ Bianco]].
title: Champagne Problems

abstract: "Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahunga" (English: "I will still love you") is a song from the Indian film [[Half Girlfriend|Half Girlfriend (film)]]. Picturised on [[Shraddha Kapoor|Shraddha Kapoor]] and [[Arjun Kapoor|Arjun Kapoor]], the song has been sung by [[Arijit Singh|Arijit Singh]] and [[Shashaa Tirupati|Shashaa Tirupati]]. The music of the song is composed by [[Mithoon|Mithoon]] and the lyrics are penned by [[Manoj Muntashir|Manoj Muntashir]]. Reprise version of the track is sung by [[Arijit Singh|Arijit Singh]] titled, "Pal Bhar (Chaahunga Reprise)", and also another version titled, "Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahungi" is sung by [[Shraddha Kapoor|Shraddha Kapoor]] along with the instrumental "Half Girlfriend (Love Theme)".
title: Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahunga

abstract: When Gaga was getting ready to film the final scene of A Star Is Born, where she sings "I'll Never Love Again", the singer got a telephone call that her childhood friend Sonja Durham was in her last moments of [[Stage IV cancer|Cancer staging]]. Gaga left the set and drove to meet Durham, but she arrived ten minutes after her friend died. She asked Durham's husband if she should return to filming; he replied, "You've gotta do what Sonja would want you to do", so she returned to the set. Co-star and director Bradley Cooper was supportive of Gaga's loss but Gaga was adamant about finishing the scene, so she stepped on the set and sang "I'll Never Love Again". The singer said, "[Sonja] gave me a tragic gift that day and I took it with me to [the] set, and I sang that song for Jackson and for her on that very same day within an hour."Along with the film version, the [[soundtrack|A Star Is Born (2018 soundtrack)]] also contains an extended version. Gaga wrote the song with [[Natalie Hemby|Natalie Hemby]], [[Hillary Lindsey|Hillary Lindsey]], and Aaron Raitiere. Both tracks were produced by Lady Gaga and Benjamin Rice. The song is performed in the key of [[G major|G major]] with a moderate [[tempo|tempo]] of 54 beats per minute in [[common time|Time signature]]. It follows a chord progression of Gadd2–Em7–Cmaj9–D9sus in the verses and Gadd2–Em7(no3)–Cmaj9/E–D9sus in the chorus. Gaga's vocals span from G3 to E5. Brian Truitt of [[USA Today|USA Today]] described the song as a "weepy" ballad.
title: I'll Never Love Again

abstract: "Pussy Print" (censored on the album as "P**** Print") is a song by American hip-hop and trap artist [[Gucci Mane|Gucci Mane]] featuring [[Kanye West|Kanye West]], from Mane's ninth studio album [[Everybody Looking|Everybody Looking]] (2016).
title: Pussy Print

abstract: Actor and director of [[A Star Is Born|A Star Is Born (2018 film)]], [[Bradley Cooper|Bradley Cooper]], had approached producer [[Dave Cobb|Dave Cobb]] for crafting the sound of the soundtrack, after listening to the latter's work. Cobb was recording an album in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville, Tennessee]] with American singer-songwriter and guitarist [[Jason Isbell|Jason Isbell]], and asked him to write a song for the soundtrack. Isbell asked to see the screenplay and got in touch with Cooper to understand his character, Jackson Maine, and his requirements regarding the track. Cooper wanted to have a realistic sounding song, which urged Isbell to put his own thoughts as a songwriter in the lyrics, resulting in "Maybe It's Time". He also tried to include the "idea of salvation and redemption throughout the story and the movie, how that's something that comes from within an individual".
title: Maybe It's Time

abstract: Chase Field, formerly Bank One Ballpark, is a [[baseball park|baseball park]] located in [[Downtown Phoenix|Downtown Phoenix]], [[Arizona|Arizona]]. It is the home of the [[Arizona Diamondbacks|Arizona Diamondbacks]], the city's [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]] (MLB) franchise. It opened in [[1998|1998 Arizona Diamondbacks season]], in time for the Diamondbacks' first game as an [[expansion team|expansion team]]. Chase Field was the first stadium built in the United States with a [[retractable roof|retractable roof]] over a natural-grass playing surface, which will be replaced by synthetic turf before the 2019 season.
title: Chase Field

abstract: Oracle Park has also played host to both professional and [[collegiate|college football]] [[American football|American football]] games. The stadium was the home of the [[Foster Farms Bowl|Foster Farms Bowl]], an annual college postseason [[bowl game|bowl game]], from its inaugural playing in 2002 until 2013 and also served as the temporary home for the [[University of California|California Golden Bears football]]'s football team in 2011. Professionally, it was the home of the [[San Francisco Demons|San Francisco Demons]] of the [[XFL|XFL]] and the [[California Redwoods|Sacramento Mountain Lions]] of the [[United Football League|United Football League (2009-)]].
title: Oracle Park

abstract: Great American Ball Park is a [[baseball stadium|baseball stadium]] in [[Cincinnati|Cincinnati]], [[Ohio|Ohio]], which is the home field of [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]]'s [[Cincinnati Reds|Cincinnati Reds]]. It opened in 2003, replacing [[Cinergy Field|Cinergy Field]] (formerly Riverfront Stadium), their home field from 1970 to 2002. The park's name comes from [[Great American Insurance Group|Great American Insurance Group]].
title: Great American Ball Park

abstract: Progressive Field is a [[baseball park|baseball park]] located in the [[downtown area|downtown Cleveland]] of [[Cleveland|Cleveland]], [[Ohio|Ohio]], United States. It is the home field of the [[Cleveland Indians|Cleveland Indians]] of [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]] and, together with [[Quicken Loans Arena|Quicken Loans Arena]], is part of the [[Gateway Sports and Entertainment Complex|Gateway Sports and Entertainment Complex]]. It was ranked as Major League Baseball's best ballpark in a 2008 [[Sports Illustrated|Sports Illustrated]] fan opinion poll.
title: Progressive Field

abstract: Luzhniki Stadium () is the [[national stadium|national stadium]] of Russia, located in its capital city, [[Moscow|Moscow]]. Its total [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 81,000 makes it the [[largest football stadium in Russia|List of football stadiums in Russia]] and [[one of the largest stadiums in Europe|List of European stadiums by capacity]]. The stadium is a part of the [[Luzhniki Olympic Complex|Luzhniki Olympic Complex]], and is located in [[Khamovniki District|Khamovniki District]] of the [[Central Administrative Okrug|Central Administrative Okrug]] of Moscow city. The name Luzhniki derives from the flood meadows in the bend of [[Moskva River|Moskva River]] where the stadium was built, translating roughly as "The Meadows".
title: Luzhniki Stadium

abstract: Broncos Stadium at Mile High, previously known as Invesco Field at Mile High and Sports Authority Field at Mile High, and commonly known as Mile High, New Mile High or Mile High Stadium, is an [[American football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]], named Mile High due to the city's elevation of . The primary tenant is the [[Denver Broncos|Denver Broncos]] of the [[National Football League|National Football League]] (NFL). It opened in 2001 to replace [[Mile High Stadium|Mile High Stadium]] and was largely paid for by taxpayers. [[Invesco|Invesco]] paid $120   million for the original naming rights, before [[Sports Authority|Sports Authority]] secured them in 2011.
title: Broncos Stadium at Mile High

abstract: Wrigley Field is a [[baseball park|baseball park]] located on the [[North Side|North Side, Chicago]] of [[Chicago|Chicago]], [[Illinois|Illinois]]. It is the home of the [[Chicago Cubs|Chicago Cubs]], one of the city's two [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]] (MLB) franchises. It first opened in 1914 as Weeghman Park for [[Charles Weeghman|Charles Weeghman]]'s [[Chicago Whales|Chicago Whales]] of the [[Federal League|Federal League]], which folded after the [[1915 baseball season|1915 in baseball]]. The Cubs played their first home game at the park on April 20, [[1916|1916 Chicago Cubs season]], defeating the [[Cincinnati Reds|1916 Cincinnati Reds season]] with a score of 7–6 in 11 innings. Chewing gum magnate [[William Wrigley Jr.|William Wrigley Jr.]] of the [[Wrigley Company|Wrigley Company]] acquired complete control of the Cubs in [[1921|1921 Chicago Cubs season]]. It was named Cubs Park from [[1920|1920 Chicago Cubs season]] to [[1926|1926 Chicago Cubs season]], before being renamed Wrigley Field in [[1927|1927 Chicago Cubs season]].
title: Wrigley Field

abstract: Pride Park Stadium, commonly known as Pride Park, is an [[all-seater|all-seater stadium]] [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Derby|Derby]], England, that is the home ground of [[English Football League|English Football League]] club [[Derby County|Derby County F.C.]]. With a capacity of 33,597, it is the [[16th-largest|List of English football stadiums by capacity]] football ground in England and the 20th-largest stadium in the United Kingdom. Located on [[Pride Park|Pride Park]], a business park on the outskirts of Derby city centre, the stadium was built as part of the commercial redevelopment of the area in the 1990s. Derby County have played at the ground since it opened in 1997 as a replacement for their former home, the [[Baseball Ground|Baseball Ground]]. Due to sponsorship, the venue was officially known as the iPro Stadium between 2013 and 2016.
title: Pride Park Stadium

abstract: Bellerive Oval (currently known as Blundstone Arena for sponsorship reasons) is a [[cricket|cricket]] and [[Australian rules football|Australian rules football]] ground located in [[Bellerive|Bellerive, Tasmania]], a suburb on the eastern shore of [[Hobart|Hobart]], [[Tasmania|Tasmania]]. It is the only venue in Tasmania which hosts international cricket matches, and has a spectator capacity of 19,500.
title: Bellerive Oval

abstract: Adelaide Oval is a sports ground in [[Adelaide|Adelaide]], [[South Australia|South Australia]], located in the [[parklands|Adelaide Parklands]] between the [[city centre|Adelaide city centre]] and [[North Adelaide|North Adelaide]]. The venue is predominantly used for [[cricket|cricket]] and [[Australian rules football|Australian rules football]], but has also played host to [[rugby league|rugby league]], [[rugby union|rugby union]], [[soccer|soccer]], [[tennis|tennis]] among other sports as well as regularly being used to hold [[concert|concerts]]. Austadiums.com described Adelaide Oval as being "one of the most picturesque [[Test cricket|Test cricket]] grounds in Australia, if not the world". After the completion of the grounds most recent redevelopment in 2014, sports journalist [[Gerard Whateley|Gerard Whateley]] described the venue as being "the most perfect piece of modern architecture because it's a thoroughly contemporary stadium with all the character that it's had in the past".
title: Adelaide Oval

abstract: The US$1 million ($ million today) project was initiated by Pittsburgh Pirates' owner [[Barney Dreyfuss|Barney Dreyfuss]], with the goal of replacing his franchise's then-current home, [[Exposition Park|Exposition Park (Pittsburgh)]]. The stadium was made of concrete and steel (one of the first of its kind) in order to increase its lifespan. The Pirates opened Forbes Field on June 30, 1909, against the [[Chicago Cubs|Chicago Cubs]], and played the final game against the Cubs on June 28, 1970. The field itself featured a large playing surface, with the [[batting cage|batting cage]] placed in the deepest part of center field during games. Seating was altered multiple times throughout the stadium's life; at times fans were permitted to sit on the grass in the outfield during [[overflow crowds|Standing-room only]]. The Pirates won three World Series while at Forbes Field and the other original tenant, the [[Pittsburgh Panthers football team|Pittsburgh Panthers football]] had five undefeated seasons before moving in 1924.
title: Forbes Field

abstract: St James' Park is a [[football|Association football]] stadium in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle upon Tyne]], England. It is the home of [[Premier League|Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United F.C.]] With a seating capacity of 52,388, it is the [[seventh largest football stadium in England|List of football stadiums in England]].
title: St James' Park

abstract: Opened on 25 October 2003 with an exhibition match between Benfica and Uruguayan club [[Nacional|Club Nacional de Football]], it replaced the [[original Estádio da Luz|Estádio da Luz (1954)]], which had 120,000 seats. The seating capacity was decreased to 65,647 and is currently set at 64,642. The stadium was designed by [[HOK Sport Venue Event|HOK Sport Venue Event]] and had a construction cost of €162   million.
title: Estádio da Luz

abstract: Home Park is a [[football|Association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Plymouth|Plymouth]], [[England|England]]. The ground, nicknamed the Theatre of Greens, has been the home of [[Football League One|Football League One]] club [[Plymouth Argyle|Plymouth Argyle F.C.]] since 1901.
title: Home Park

abstract: Murrayfield Stadium is a sports [[stadium|stadium]] located in the west end of [[Edinburgh|Edinburgh]], the capital of [[Scotland|Scotland]]. Its all-seater capacity is 67,144 which makes it the largest stadium in Scotland and the fifth largest in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]].
title: Murrayfield Stadium

abstract: Lang Park, also known as Brisbane Stadium, and by the [[sponsored|Naming rights]] name Suncorp Stadium, is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Brisbane|Brisbane]], [[Queensland|Queensland]], Australia, located in the suburb of [[Milton|Milton, Queensland]]. The current facility comprises a three-tiered rectangular sporting stadium with a capacity of 52,500 people. It is primarily used for [[rugby league|rugby league]], [[rugby union|rugby union]], and [[soccer|soccer]], with a rectangular [[playing field|pitch (sports field)]] of 136 metres by 82 metres.
title: Lang Park

abstract: Bosse Field is a baseball stadium located in [[Evansville, Indiana|Evansville, Indiana]]. Opened in 1915, it was the first municipally owned sports stadium in the [[United States|United States]] and is the third-oldest ballpark still in regular use for professional baseball, surpassed only by [[Fenway Park|Fenway Park]] (1912) in [[Boston|Boston]] and [[Wrigley Field|Wrigley Field]] (1914) in [[Chicago|Chicago]].
title: Bosse Field

abstract: Borchert Field was a [[baseball park|baseball park]] in [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin|Wisconsin]], United States.
