The home field for several professional baseball clubs from 1888 through 1952, it became obsolete after the construction of [[County Stadium|Milwaukee County Stadium]] in 1953 and was demolished later that year. The site is now covered by [[Interstate 43|Interstate 43 in Wisconsin]].The park was built on a rectangular block bounded by North 7th, 8th, Chambers, and Burleigh Streets. Home plate was at the south end (Chambers), with the outfield bounded by the outer fence, making fair territory [[home-plate|Baseball field#Home plate]]-shaped, with short fields in left and right and very deep power alleys, a configuration used by a number of ballparks of the era that were constrained by a narrow block.
title: Borchert Field

abstract: Stadion Kantrida is a [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in the [[Croatia|Croatian]] city of [[Rijeka|Rijeka]]. It is named after the Kantrida neighbourhood in which it is located, in the western part of the city. It has served as home of the football club [[HNK Rijeka|HNK Rijeka]] for most years since 1946. The stadium has a distinctive appearance as it is situated between steep cliffs, a remnant of an old quarry, just north of the stadium and the shore of the [[Adriatic|Adriatic Sea]] on its south side.
title: Stadion Kantrida

abstract: Robina Stadium, also known by its [[sponsored name|Naming rights]] Cbus Super Stadium, is a rectangular [[football|football]] stadium in the [[Gold Coast|Gold Coast, Queensland]] suburb of [[Robina|Robina, Queensland]], [[Queensland|Queensland]]. The main usage is as the home ground to the [[National Rugby League|National Rugby League]]'s [[Gold Coast Titans|Gold Coast Titans]].
title: Robina Stadium

abstract: Arena Joaquim Américo Guimarães is the home stadium of [[Club Athletico Paranaense|Club Athletico Paranaense]]. It is located in [[Curitiba|Curitiba]], the state capital of [[Paraná|Paraná (state)]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. Known as Arena da Baixada, the football stadium was the first in Brazil to sell its [[naming rights|naming rights]]. It was known as Kyocera Arena between 2005 and 1 April 2008. Additionally, the stadium is perhaps best known for being the first [[retractable roof|retractable roof]] stadium in [[South America|South America]]. With Curitiba selected as one of the host cities of [[World Cup 2014|World Cup 2014]], the arena between 2012 and 2014 was rebuilt. Its capacity was expanded to 42,372 seats.
title: Arena da Baixada

abstract: Thialf is an ice arena in [[Heerenveen|Heerenveen]], [[Netherlands|Netherlands]]. The stadium is used for [[long track speed skating|long track speed skating]], [[short track speed skating|short track speed skating]], [[ice hockey|ice hockey]], [[figure skating|figure skating]], [[ice speedway|ice speedway]], and non-sports events. The outdoor rink was opened in 1967, and the indoor stadium was opened in 1986. Several world records were set in the indoor stadium. Annually, Thialf hosts two [[Speed Skating World Cup|ISU Speed Skating World Cup]] events. The arena has a capacity of 12,500 seats. [[Jan de Jong|Jan de Jong]] was the ice rink master at Thialf for many years.
title: Thialf

abstract: Estádio José Pinheiro Borda, better known as Estádio Beira-Rio (, Riverside Stadium) due to its location beside the [[Guaíba River|Guaíba River]], is a football stadium in [[Porto Alegre|Porto Alegre]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. It serves as the home stadium for [[Sport Club Internacional|Sport Club Internacional]], replacing their previous stadium, the [[Estádio dos Eucaliptos|Estádio dos Eucaliptos]]. It is named after José Pinheiro Borda, an elderly Portuguese engineer who supervised the building of the stadium but died before seeing its completion.
title: Estádio Beira-Rio

abstract: The Free State Stadium (), currently known as the Toyota Stadium for sponsorship reasons and formerly known as Vodacom Park, is a stadium in [[Bloemfontein|Bloemfontein]], [[South Africa|South Africa]], used mainly for [[rugby union|rugby union]] and also sometimes for [[association football|association football]]. It was originally built for the [[1995 Rugby World Cup|1995 Rugby World Cup]], and was one of the venues for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 FIFA World Cup]].
title: Free State Stadium

abstract: TCF Bank Stadium is an outdoor stadium located on the campus of the [[University of Minnesota|University of Minnesota]] in [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota|Minnesota]], United States. Opened in [[2009|2009 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team]], it is the home field of the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers|Minnesota Golden Gophers football]] of the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten Conference]], and the temporary home of [[Minnesota United FC|Minnesota United FC]] of [[Major League Soccer|Major League Soccer]]. The stadium also served as the temporary home of the [[Minnesota Vikings|Minnesota Vikings]] of the [[National Football League|National Football League]] (NFL) for the 2014 and 2015 seasons during the construction of [[U.S. Bank Stadium|U.S. Bank Stadium]]. The 50,805-seat "[[horseshoe|horseshoe]]" style stadium cost $303.3   million to build and is designed to support future expansion to seat up to 80,000.
title: TCF Bank Stadium
